webTitle: The rise and fall of internet shares is the start of something far bigger

fields.headline: That was then, this is e-now
fields.standfirst:
The rise and fall of internet shares is the start of something far bigger
Net news
fields.trailText: The internet has not only created more millionaires than any phenomenon in history: it has also created more myths, led by the wildly whacky idea that infinite wealth can be created indefinitely out of nothing.
fields.body:
The internet has not only created more millionaires than any phenomenon in history: it has also created more myths, led by the wildly whacky idea that infinite wealth can be created indefinitely out of nothing.

That belief has been exploded by the collapse in the value of dotcom firms' shares, a crash only less stupendous than the previous boom. The proprietors of e-retailer Jungle.com, for example, thought only a few months ago that their baby might be worth £700 million. Yet GUS has just bought Jungle for £37m.

Before lamenting too loudly, though, reconsider the facts. That's still a juicy fortune, and not a bad return on a year or two's work - not to mention a loss-making business.

There were always two web worlds: the investor mania for dotcom companies existed in outer space, while the growth of internet business, usage and applications, was in the real world, where these activities proliferate and thrive. The two worlds were connected by money. Dotcom firms could in effect print their own wealth. This encouraged the formation and flotation of many start-ups, but also generated a tidal wave of hype.

Even so, the internet (while of huge importance) is only the tip of the hi-tech iceberg. A vast and growing army of specialists supports the websites and earns large profits. Of the 10 fastest-growing US companies listed by Fortune magazine this month, three are deeply involved in cyberspace. Thus, Network Appliance sells one web storage filer weekly to Yahoo! alone (sales $579 million, net income $73.8m, annual sales growth 80 per cent). Even bigger is I2 Technologies, which manages supply chains for trading on the net (sales $750.5m, net income $58.4m, sales growth 71 per cent). Another star is Diamond Tech Partners (sales $136.2m, net income $16.2m, sales growth 50 per cent), which helps develop and equip e-strategies for massive firms. It set up Covinst, the gigantic exchange over which America's Big Three carmak ers are to buy components.

Europe's giant retailers are evenly split between rivals: World-Wide Retail Exchange (backed by Wal-Mart and Tesco) and GlobalNetExchange (Sears, Carrefour, Sainsbury etc). The profits from such e-ventures may never be visible: they consist mainly of savings.

By the same token, the value of EasyJet's now dominant e-booking is hidden. It lies in lower costs, in the creation of an improved business model in which customers do much of the clerical work. That helps achieve the airline's prime aim: enough volume at high enough prices to earn a nourishing margin.

This is a simple, universal economic formula that clever e-entrepreneurs (and their even smarter financiers) have stupidly ignored. In cold truth, many e-entrepreneurs earned their multi-millions, not from the businesses, but the financing. That proved a double disaster. Many failed to discover viable income. Many let the initial financing money go to their heads. They spent like established companies when they were merely start-ups that often had little idea how to make people pay for their services.

The consequent travails have created yet another myth - this time, that real-life, big, established compa nies, once they have mastered e-commerce (with the aid of specialists such as Diamond Tech), will dominate the new world as they do the old.

Consultancy E-Insight thus forecasts that by 2008 Tesco alone will generate $500m, a third of its worldwide net profits, from cyberspace, leaving retail food upstarts sprawling behind. That will be its reward for enduring £400m of losses and investment over the next five years.

In so fast-changing a market, forecasts eight years out are exceedingly chancy: also, much of the giants' e-commerce traffic will be cannibalised from existing stores.

Giants at least have the apparent advantages of estab lished brands and abundant funds, but these are only as good as their exploitation. Overwhelming evidence shows that new boys and girls, untrammelled by mental and physical bricks and mortar, are far better than oldsters at developing new markets and wealth. The earlier gross abundance of e-finance was thus a curse in disguise for the web millionaires. They behaved like fat cats when they should have acted like starving moggies .

The best will start again, redesign business models to achieve genuinely sustainable revenue and reduce costs to match. Some will sell out to established firms, which should cherish the independent talents of an entrepreneurial acquisition, and make it the nucleus of new, distinctive growth. The typical behaviour, however, is to absorb the purchase and crush it to death. Young entrepreneurs, especially when fortified with millions, will run off to the next new thing.

That is another reality of the web. Newcomers can move into action at potentially devastating speed. In no other age have the opportunities and the chances for entrepreneurs been so rich and abundant. Even those whose outlets are mundane can exploit the web to enhance their prospects. The e-stock boom is no doubt over. But in the real e-world, you ain't seen nothing yet.

 Robert Heller's latest book, 'Riding the Revolution', is published by HarperCollins, priced at £20.

webTitle: Student finance: Pennywise, but not pound foolish

fields.headline: Pennywise, but not pound foolish
fields.standfirst: From debt counsellors to hitting the (secondhand) books, every little helps, particularly when it comes to accomodation and insurance
fields.trailText: From debt counsellors to hitting the (secondhand) books, every little helps, particularly when it comes to accomodation and insurance.
fields.body:
As a student struggling to make ends meet, you need all the help you can get. Here are some tips for making the most of a limited budget:

1 Most banks have student counsellors or advisers on campus or in branches nearby. They will be more than happy to help you work out a budget, and will usually be sympathetic about extending overdrafts, provided you keep them informed.

2 Work out what your week's spending money is after paying for necessities such as rent, gas and electricity. Leave the amount you need to spend on necessities in your bank account, but take your spending money out as cash at the start of every week. You know then that what you've got in your wallet is what you've got to spend.

3 Keep a tally of what you are spending. Filling in cheque stubs and keeping a list of cash outgoings will help you identify impulse buys and decide where you can cut back.

4 Make sure that you are not going to be charged for using a cash machine that doesn't belong to your bank. Every pound counts.

5 Try to buy secondhand books. Reading lists can often cost hundreds of pounds, but if you wait until you get to college, you will find second-year students keen to offload books from their first year - often in pristine condition.

6 If you take on a part-time job to reduce your debts, make sure you don't pay unnecessary tax. You can earn up to £4,385 in the current tax year, or £84 a week, without paying any income tax, although you will have to make National Insurance contributions on any earnings over £76 a week. If you think that your total taxable income in the whole of the tax year is likely to be less than your personal allowance, you should mention this to your employer when you start work and ask for a form P38(S). Fill in and sign the form before handing it back to your employer to complete.

Your employer should then pay you without deducting tax. If your total income is more than the personal allowance, you will have to pay tax on the difference. Your employer will deduct tax under PAYE. If your pay is more than £76 each week, your employer will also deduct NI contributions. The Inland Revenue publishes a leaflet - IR60 - on students and income tax. It is available on the Revenue website: www.inlandrevenue.org.uk.

7 Apply for money from other sources. Freefund. com lists more than 85,000 bursaries and scholarships totalling £100 million in value available in the UK. Some are highly specific, such as the Dorothy May Edwards Charity bursary of £3,100 for candidates who have attended Ysgol Pantycelyn in Llandovery. But others are more general, such as the deo.com scholarship for £750, which is open to students with a genuine interest in music. Companies may also give financial assistance to students who do work placements with them before or during university.

8 For information on student loans, grants and tuition fees, visit the Department for Education and Employment's website, www.dfee.gov.uk/studentsupport or call 0800 731 9133 for the booklet 'Financial Support for Higher Education Students in 2000/2001'.

Low life, high risk

Students are very popular with burglars. Home Office research has found that neighbourhoods dominated by students living in privately rented accommodation attract criminals 'like bees to a honeypot'.

They are drawn by poor security, the fact that properties are often left empty for many hours a day, and the readily portable, high-value electronic equipment that students tend to own.

Parents can apply to have their own contents insurance extended to include their children's property at college. But insurance broker Alan Broad of Summit Insurance Services says such cover is often too restrictive. Policies may only cover belongings in the student's room; if there is a theft, the insurer may demand proof of forcible entry.

However, several insurers have designed student policies that do not require visible evidence of a physical break-in. Broad recommends policies from Axa, Saxon and Campus (details can be found on his website, www.studentwatchout.co.uk).

Endsleigh, the specialist student insurer, offers two main possessions policies - one for students in halls of residence and one for those in private rented accommodation. Cover for possessions worth £3,000 costs from £18 to £150, depending on where you live. Insurance for mobile phones (a flat rate of £30), and bikes (from £40 to £227, depending on the value of the bike and where you live) can be added to the basic cover. Endsleigh has branches on many campuses and can be contacted direct by phone on 01242 866866.

Bedsit? Just ask my dad

Rental property in university towns is notorious for being overpriced and dilapidated. By buying a property for their student offspring, parents can ensure they have decent accommodation and provide an investment for their future.

William Legard has bought a house for each of his daughters, Arabella and Victoria. Each house - one in Bristol and one in Newcastle - has seven bedrooms, which means Mr Legard could rent to other students in each location. 'This covers the mortgage and provides some extra which can be used for repairs and maintenance,' he says.

He requires a month's rent in advance as a bond, some of which is used to pay for the houses to be cleaned when students move on. Each set of six students sign up together, agreeing to cover the rent for any individual who fails to make the monthly payment.

Rent is collected by a professional agent, but Arabella, who has now completed her zoology degree, and Victoria, who is about to study in France for a year, have kept an eye on what repairs are needed.

Mortgage interest and maintenance costs can be set against profits, reducing tax liability. In the meantime the properties are increasing in value, gains which will not be potentially liable to capital gains tax until the houses are sold or transferred. Both properties have been bought in Legard's own name, on the advice of his mortgage broker John Charcol, as this enabled him to borrow more competitively. However he intends to transfer the properties to his daughters as an investment.

Provided he lives for seven years after transferring the properties, his daughters will not have to pay inheritance tax on the gifts, even if they sell their houses.

As a property developer, spotting properties has obviously been easier for Legard than other parents. He has converted the Bristol property from seven separate bedsits into a whole house, providing a bedroom, en suite bathroom and study for each occupant.

However, he would recommend the idea to any par ent who can afford the outlay.

'When your children are 19 to 21, it's a wonderful way of getting them on the property ladder,' he said. 'They will have the option of keeping them on as an investment, providing a good income, or selling them to provide a deposit for a house wherever they want to buy.'

webTitle: London Stock Exchange faces fresh onslaught

fields.headline: Exchange faces fresh onslaught
fields.trailText: The battle over the London Stock Exchange will intensify this week as OM Group releases the formal offer document for its £808 million bid, and Exchange chairman Don Cruickshank faces a hostile audience at its annual meeting on Thursday.
fields.body:
The battle over the London Stock Exchange will intensify this week as OM Group releases the formal offer document for its £808 million bid, and Exchange chairman Don Cruickshank faces a hostile audience at its annual meeting on Thursday.

The Swedish group will press its case for a takeover as the only credible way forward for the Exchange. It will underline its excellent record, superior technology and its management skills, contrasting these with the Exchange's 'outdated' idea of merging with Frankfurt.

Cruickshank is expected to mount a strong defence of that merger at Thursday's annual meeting. The Exchange sees the deal as central to its battle against OM's bid and remains convinced it is the right way forward. But he is unlikely to offernew evidence in favour of the merger, nor to answer questions on key areas such as settlement and trading.

The Exchange believes it is constrained by being in a formal offer period because of the OM bid. But it is also likely to keep its best ammunition for later in the battle.

A number of broking firms are, however, expected to protest by voting against Cruickshank's election as chairman and the reappointment of Gavin Casey as chief executive and Michael Marks as deputy chairman. 'There will be some protest votes' said Justin Urquhart-Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers.

Another large international firm said it would not vote against the directors, but added that this was simply because now is not a good time for a wholesale change in management: 'It is in the interests of stability. We do not want it to be seen as tacit approval of the board.'

Shareholders, most of whom are also brokers using the Exchange's services, are angry at the lack of detail on key areas such as settlement and clearing systems, regulation - even which trading systems will be used. And there is concern that ownership of the joint-venture company, to be called iX, will be split between the exchanges, which, they say, fails to recognise London's superior position.

The Exchange's position was undermined last week in a leaked report, commissioned by one of its advisers, Merrill Lynch, outlining these issues and calling it a 'nightmare' to implement. Merrill insists, however, that it backs the proposals.

webTitle: How to get a good reputation

fields.headline: Get a good reputation
fields.body:
1 RECOGNISE that people often develop completely undeserved reputations: 'Saint' John Hume, the Northern Irish MP, is probably one of the most irritable parliamentarians in the UK, while, more seriously, former South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje was known for his honesty until he admitted taking bribes. 'You have to do some preparation, and it helps if it bears some relation to reality,' says Brendan, an expert office politician. Decide what reputation you want - intelligent, dependable or big-hearted, perhaps - and reinforce this image at suitable opportunities. David 'Two Brains' Willetts, Shadow Social Security Secretary, is known for tackling difficult intellectual subjects, but read his pamphlets, and you may not be so convinced.

2 RECRUIT other people to spread your propaganda. Sir Bob Horton (the former BP and Railtrack chief) lost fans when he said he was quicker-witted than other people. Politicians are forever slapping each other on the back, because they know that they are more likely to be described as remarkable if they give out the bonbons, too. Brendan says: 'You can try saying to Fred "You're so good at doing X. We're a good team." Then Fred is more likely to go round saying you are good at Y.'

3 UNDERSTAND that 'there is a need for people who are seen as wonderful, self-sacrificing and good,' says former teacher Lisa. 'Often you find that people with that reputation are s**ts, but if you get the lingo right, you can get away with anything.' Most of us enjoy being able to identify a few characters around us, especially if they come from an otherwise dull profession. Media darling and QC George Carman hit the front pages when he announced his retirement. Flamboyance, wit, hard work and talent had propelled him into the limelight.

4 CONSIDER building your reputation indirectly and subtly. Many people have carved out attractive personas on the strength of a strong hobby. Former Prime Minister John Major's interest in cricket helped reinforce his reputation as decent, dependable and thoroughly English. But do not go too far: Tory leader William Hague became an object of fun when he insisted he drank 14 pints a day as a teenager.

5 FIND the niche that suits you best. Betty Boothroyd has been hailed as an outstanding Speaker of the House of Commons, but she made little mark in her decades as a rather lacklustre backbench MP.

webTitle: Help - How can I get subsidies for further education?

fields.headline: Help - How can I get subsidies for further education?
fields.trailText: Whether you are interested in learning a language or improving your IT skills, you could qualify for a government subsidy on your tuition costs.
fields.body:
Whether you are interested in learning a language or improving your IT skills, you could qualify for a government subsidy on your tuition costs of up to £150. Many further education courses start this week, so now is a good time to find out about the possibilities.

If you wanted to do the one-year A/S level course in French at Canterbury College, you would normally pay £120 for the tuition and £45 for the exam. But under the Government's Individual Learning Account (ILA), you could save most of that: you have to pay £25 of the course fees and the Government will pay the next £150. To qualify you need to be in work, the course must qualify for ILA and you must be one of the first million people to join (this threshold has not been reached yet).

(There are other exclusions, such as driving lessons, professional qualifications and courses regarded as higher education.)

The Government is also offering 20 per cent discounts to people in the second year of a course where they have already had the £150 subsidy. Discounts of 80 per cent are available on certain IT and maths courses.

A word of caution: we are in transition between a wide network of local pilot schemes to central administration. Under the pilots, many local providers gave students vouchers worth £150, but these have to be used up by the end of the year. If you are applying centrally under the new national scheme, you should receive an account card and an annual statement, so you can carry forward any unused allowance to future years.

webTitle: Student finance: Surviving the school of hard knocks

fields.headline: Surviving the school of hard knocks
fields.standfirst: As many as 30,000 A-level students are forsaking university this year because of debt fears.  Jill Insley  on ways to prevent a new form of brain drain
fields.trailText: As many as 30,000 A-level students are forsaking university this year because of debt fears. Jill Insley on ways to prevent a new form of brain drain.
fields.body:
Starting college in the next few weeks? Congratulations: in three years' time you can look forward to being the proud possessor of a degree - and debts of about £24,000.

Unless your parents have deep pockets - and are willing to dip into them on a regular basis - you will end up meeting your own living costs during higher education, and possibly tuition fees as well. Total student debt is estimated to stand at £3.5bn in the UK, and only 45 per cent of students feel they can access enough money, according to Barclays Bank.

Andrew Wilkinson is just entering his second year at St Andrews in Scotland, where he is studying history. He has already used a £2,700 student loan, and has spent the summer working to pay off a £500 overdraft. Even though ways to spend money are limited in St Andrews, he expects to owe about £8,000 at the end of his four-year course. 'The cost of living - food and other basic things - is really shocking. And it's probably worse for people studying in cities like Edinburgh, where there's the temptation of clubs and a better range of shops.'

The increased cost of studying since the abolition of grants in 1998 has forced many students to take on jobs during term time. Twenty-five per cent of students claim to work 40 hours or more a week to supplement their income, while a further 18 per cent say they work for more than 30 hours, according to research by a special bursary website, freefund.com. Nearly half felt that working was having a detrimental effect on their studies and overall grades.

The prospect of heavy debt has proved too daunting for others. Freefund.com found that some 30,000 A-level students this year have decided not to continue with their education because of the financial burden. Iain Aitken, its managing director, says: 'This is another terrible form of the brain drain. We have thousands of talented students who, because of cost, are having their development stunted. And as student debt continues to increase, this problem is set to worsen.'

The situation has become so severe that competitions are now dropping free holidays and cars in favour of educational funding as preferred prizes. The Evening Standard in London has been running a draw for funding of £15,000 over three years, while Coca- Cola has been auctioning a higher education package worth up to £25,000 on its website. Bidding for the package, which has proved the most popular item in the auction so far, ends tonight at 10pm.

Coca-Cola's UK communications director, Andrew Coker, said the company had been 'staggered' by the demand for a student fees and expenses prize when it surveyed customers on what they wanted as auction items. 'Our understanding of the group that we researched - 16-to-28-year-olds - was that they wanted round-the-world trips, tickets to first-night shows, exclusive parties and other entertainment-based things. But what came back was a much more serious-minded response. They wanted help to pay for education that would help them achieve the lifestyle they wanted.'

Coca-Cola's research indicates that young people are now well aware of the considerable career advantages that education can provide. Today's students are the high earners of tomorrow: having a degree could add some £400,000 to lifetime earnings, according to Robert Skidelsky of the Social Market Foundation. The benefits can be felt straight after graduation, with City firms such as Andersen Consulting offering bonuses of £10,000 to attract the cream of graduates.

Not surprisingly, financial institutions - particularly the high street banks - are keen to sign up students as soon as possible. A customer nurtured through three years of college and several years of debt thereafter is likely to become a lucrative and loyal source of business.

But while banks have traditionally competed on the value of 'freebies', such as vouchers for clothes, and CDs, the focus has now moved on to the size of overdraft and credit on offer. HSBC's Richard Beck says: 'In the past two or three years we've seen a slightly more realistic attitude develop amongst students. There's less choosing on the basis of freebies and more interest in overdrafts, local support, free borrowing and structured arrangements for repayment after university.'

Martin Preater, student business officer at the Bath University branch of Barclays, agrees: 'People are changing from debt avoidance to debt management. If students are purely reliant on student loans, they usually come to see us within two to three months.'

Students who are blasé about money management could face more than repayment problems in the future.

Mortgage lenders subtract annual repayments on outstanding loans from your gross annual salary before calculating how much you can borrow, so a large amount of student debt could easily prevent you getting the home you want.

Worse still, some potential employers, particularly banks and other financial institutions, are wary of taking on recruits with a poor credit history.

Caroline Andrews, a spokeswoman for Barclays, says credit references are checked if a job is being offered to an external candidate.'It would depend on the job being offered as to whether it makes a difference. But at the end of the day, our first responsibility is to our customers.'

The drama of making ends meet

Rachel Lane has only been at university for one year, but she has already built up debts of more than £4,000. By the end of her three-year course in drama at Brunel University, she could easily owe more than £12,000.

Although Rachel claims not to be extravagant, spending about £10 a week on food, and £15 to £20 on going out, she has used up a £3,400 student loan, and the whole of her £750 overdraft with HSBC bank.

She has tried to limit the damage by working as a waitress in the University's conference suites during term, and worked in a factory this summer to reduce her debts - earning £4 an hour for packing and putting handles on metal jigs. She's coming up to her eighth week in the factory and has now paid off her overdraft.

However, her expenses are about to rise. Last academic year, her costs were contained by the fact that she lived in university accommodation, costing just £45 a week including bills. But this year she is moving into a house with friends: her weekly rent will be £66 excluding bills.

Rachel intends to take on a second job, probably bar work, when she returns to college this autumn, and has applied for a music lover's scholarship she found through the website freefund.com. But she says: 'It's incredibly daunting. I'm very worried about how to repay the money. If I go into acting, the likelihood of me being able to pay off the loan is remote. It puts me off the idea of doing doing a post-graduate course, which I would love to do.'

Bank on an interest-free overdraft

Size matters when choosing a bank account. The amount that can be borrowed as an interest-free overdraft will be the deciding factor for most students choosing a bank this year. Several, including Bank of Scotland, Lloyds TSB and Smile, offer overdraft facilities of up to £2,000 for people taking four- or five-year courses. The most available for those on the average three-year course is £1,800, from Smile and its parent, the Co-operative Bank.

Applicants are not guaranteed to receive the maximum advertised. However, Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds TSB, the Co-op and Smile all say it is rare for students not to be granted the full amount unless they ask for less, or have misused an account in the past.

NatWest is not advertising a maximum interest-free overdraft limit this year, preferring to negotiate individually. This makes comparing its student account with rivals' more difficult, but it is worth considering as NatWest's unauthorised overdraft interest rate is the lowest on the market, at 17.81 per cent equivalent annual rate.

webTitle: Dixons eyes World Online internet deal

fields.headline: Dixons eyes World Online internet deal
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Electrical retail giant Dixons has held informal talks exploring options to link Freeserve, its internet subsidiary, with World Online, the Dutch company which last week announced a £3.4 billion merger with Italian rival Tiscali.
fields.body:
Electrical retail giant Dixons has held informal talks exploring options to link Freeserve, its internet subsidiary, with World Online, the Dutch company which last week announced a £3.4 billion merger with Italian rival Tiscali.

The fact that Dixons and World Online have held exploratory discussions in recent months heightens expectations that Freeserve may end up part of the combined company. Another option would involve swapping equity stakes. A City source said: 'It would be naïve to think the two companies haven't talked. When World Online announced it was talking to Tiscali, it said it was also talking to several other companies.'

It is understood that nothing came of the talks, but further discussions are considered likely. However, the source suggested any deal would not be imminent: 'The Tiscali-World Online merger will take time to go through. They won't finish due diligence until December.'

The World Online-Tiscali deal is seen as a watershed deal which will prompt further consolidation in the internet access sector. The combined company will have a network of internet service providers spanning 15 countries and will be the market leader in Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Italy and the Netherlands.

The company will have 6.1 million internet subscribers; Deutsche Telekom's T-Online ISP has just 3.5 million. The new company will also have a £1bn cash pile to help finance further acquisitions.

However, T-Online has a market capitalisation of around £7.5bn, and analysts believe it is in a strong position to consolidate its position in the market place.

The German firm held takeover talks with Freeserve earlier this year, but the deal fell through after the two sides failed to agree a price. Analysts are speculating that the Tiscali-World Online deal will put greater pressure on Freeserve to find a partner.

The Tiscali deal closes a chapter on one of the internet sector's most controversial companies. World Online's share price haemorrhaged after it floated in March.

At one stage earlier this year World Online was valued at more than £35bn. But investors panicked when they discovered that the company's founder and chairwoman, Nina Brink, had sold most of her shareholding before the company floated.

webTitle: Shopping in... Italy

fields.headline: Shopping in... Italy
fields.standfirst: Where to get the best deals on Armani, Gucci and the other big names in fashion
fields.trailText: Where to get the best deals on Armani, Gucci and the other big names in fashion
fields.body:
Italy's fashion houses do not advertise these stores, some refuse to admit their existence, but once you know where they are you need never pay high-street prices again.

Rotating around the mother ship of Milan are discreet towns and suburbs with outlets offering massive discounts on top-brand clothes and accessories.

The fashion houses bypass conventional retailers to sell directly to the public, wiping out mark-ups which can account for half the price. But to avoid a retailer revolt they tend to keep it quiet, so quiet that many fashion insiders are ignorant of the bargains on their doorstep. After agreeing to supply addresses for this article, several leading houses changed their mind. Cats out of bags and all that. They are also concerned that too high a profile might debase brands by exuding a whiff of cheapness. Much of the stock comes from seconds or showroom collections, but not all. Discounts of up to 70% are common.

But it took a Dutch woman, Theodora Van Meurs, to blow the whistle by writing a bargain hunting guide to Italy: Lo Scoprioccasioni (Editoriale Shopping Italia, tel: 0039 02 7063 4605), now in its fourth edition. For £9 you get 2,000 addresses. Most of the outlets are in the triangle between Turin, Milan and Florence.

No-frills flights can make it cheaper to fly from Stansted to Milan than to Edinburgh. Go (0845 60 54321) flies from £88 return.

Armani

Armani Factory Store
Provinciale per Bregnano, 12, Vertemate (near Como). Tel: 0039 031 887 373.
Open: 9.30am-7pm, closed Monday.

Three storeys of clothes and accessories straight from the Emporio production line. A lot of beige and taupe. Coats £145, trousers £29, shirts £14.50, jeans £14.50.

Antinea
Via Stazione, 93, Trissino (near Vicenza). Tel: 0039 0445 424 100.
Open 9am-7pm, Monday 3pm-7pm.

More Emporio Armani, including seconds. A lot of wool. Suits £125, trousers £48, seconds' jeans £14.

Diesel

Surplus Diesel
Via Ponticello, 34, Molvena (near Vicenza). Tel: 0039 0424 411 811.
Open: 9am-12.30pm, 3.30pm-7.30pm, Wednesday 9am-7pm.

Contrived bargain-basement atmosphere. Remainders and seconds on the first floor. Section for children. T-shirts and jeans £12-£18.

Dolce & Gabbano

Dolce Saverio
Via Rossini, 70, Legnano (near Milan). Tel: 0039 0331 545 888.
Open: 10am-1.30pm, 2.30pm-7pm, closed Tuesday.

Remains from the first line. Suits £120-£145. Also shoes.

Fontana di Trebbia
Via Trebbia, 26, Milan Tel: 0039 02 5519 4353.
Open: 8am-12.30pm, 2am-5.30pm, closed Saturday.

Bags and suitcases from Fontana and Dolce & Gabbana, in vivid colours from £20.

Gucci

Gucci
Via Aretina, 63, Leccio Reggello (near Florence). Tel: 0039 055 865 7775.
Open: 9am-6pm, Tuesday 9am-1pm.

Spacious and luxurious surroundings. Ties £14, linen jackets £280, shoes £18, classic bags £240.

Jill Sander

Emporio Lario 1898
Via Vittorio Veneto, 52, Cirimido (near Como) Tel: 0039 031 352 3111
Open: 9.30-7pm.

Jill Sander footwear and boots £30. Also Lario shoes.

Prada

I Pellettieri d'Italia
Localita Levanella, 69, Montevarchi (near Arezzo). Tel: 0039 0978 9188
Open: 9.30-1, 2-6.30

The Japanese are on to this one, so be prepared to enter a scrum. Prada bags from around £100, ties and scarves £14, shoes £48.

Valentino

New Marbas
Via Croppina, 8, Parre (near Bergamo). Tel: 0039 035 702 141.
Open: 4.30pm-6.30pm, closed Saturday.

Sweaters mostly, £12. Also stocks Alfred Dunhill and Polo.

Ferre and GM Venturi

Italiana Manifatture
Via San Petronilla, 15, Teramo (central Italy) Tel: 0039 085 894 2141
Open: 9.30am-12.30pm, 4.30am-8pm, closed Monday during winter.

Factory prices for sport and casual gear. Also stocks from Valentino and Filippo Alpi.

fields.headline: Guiding site
fields.standfirst: www.whatsonwhen.com
fields.trailText: www.whatsonwhen.com
fields.body:
I don't like culture.
Then you should take the Eurostar to Belgium before October 15. Je n'Aime pas la Culture is a retrospective of 20th-century history, highlighting cartoons.

Where did you stumble across that?
On the impressive What's On When site. I said I was interested in literature, and it came up with lots of suggestions - including the 2000 Oslo Ibsen Festival and the Saraswati festival in Indonesia, where books are given to the goddess to be blessed.

I've already booked a week in St Lucia.
Searching by destination is possible too. What's On When is fantastically detailed: it can tell you when the autumn equinox at Chichen Itza takes place, the best place to see the next meteor shower or the date of the White Nights party in St Petersburg.

Nothing to criticise at all?
I did wonder why an ad for the Reader's Digest Guide to Vitamins and Minerals kept popping up in the listings, but the site has to make money somehow. But few mainstream guides would tell you to visit London's Smithfield market - let alone what to look for when you're there.

webTitle: Somewhere for later

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Portugal | Florida/Nevada | Sri Lanka
fields.body:
Europe

Portugal: A weekend at the Lapa Palace hotel in Lisbon from November 1 to February 1 2001 (exclu Christmas and new Year) costs £510 per couple, excluding flights. Either stay four nights for the price of three, or three plus dinner at the hotel's Ristorante Hotel Cipriani. Orient Express Hotels 0800 181 123.

France: Seven-nights skiing package for £345 in Morzine Village includes return flights from London to Geneva plus transfers, breakfast and three-course evening meals. Offer valid from December 16- April 14. Travel Deals 020-7371 1113.

Italy: Pamper yourself with seven nights at the five-star Hotel President in Abano Terme, one hour's drive from Venice. The price of £1,032 per person valid in November includes return flights, transfers, B&B, ozone bath and massage, and fangotherapy. Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898).

North America

Florida/Nevada: Two-centre holiday consisting on five nights' room-only accommodation in both Orlando and Las Vegas from £449 per person, based on twin sharing, and including return flights from Heathrow on United Airlines. Valid for selected departures between November and March 2001. Peregor Travel 01895 630871.

Canada: Wake up on Christmas morning or New Year's Day in the Canadian Rockies on a 12-day winter break with Great Rail Journeys travelling from Toronto to Vancouver (01904 521940). The package, departing either December 20 or 27 for £1,650 per person, includes return flights from Heathrow plus excursions in and around Toronto, Vancouver and Niagara Falls.

New York: Christmas shopping in the Big Apple with four-night packages in November/ early December from £579 per person including return flights with British Airways or American Airlines from Heathrow, Gatwick or Manchester to New York, and three-star hotel. Contact Major Travel 020-393 1069.

Asia

Sri Lanka: Relax in a lakeside community in Ulpotha from December 24 to January 7. Yoga sessions are optional, along with herbal steam baths and native Ayurvedic oil treatments. Price £1,450 full board exclu flights. Neals Yard Agency (0870 444 2702).

Africa

South Africa: Earthwatch, the international science and conservation charity, is offering two-week projects treating oil-soaked penguins and tagging sea birds on Robben Island throughout the first half of 2001, priced at £1,265. Accommodation and food included in the price but flights are extra. Earthwatch (01865 318 831)

webTitle: Where to go diving during winter

fields.headline: Where to go diving during winter
fields.standfirst:
I am looking for a week's diving holiday in November where beginners and more experienced divers are both catered for. Budgets are tight and warm weather is a must - any suggestions, websites etc?
Abigail Smith
fields.trailText: I am looking for a week's diving holiday in November where beginners and more experienced divers are both catered for. Budgets are tight and warm weather is a must - any suggestions, websites etc?
fields.body:
· I did my PADI training in Malindi, on the Kenyan coast north of Mombasa, one November. I don't have prices but it's an established resort with an off-shore protected area for diving which was wonderful. You could also consider Zanzibar or Sri Lanka.
Enjoy!

Cristyn Emmett

· Come to Pandan, a beautiful private island in the Philippines. We're about 20 miles from Apo Reef, we have a fantastic house reef, and we cater for everyone from absolute beginners to the very experienced. Check out our website (www.pandan.com or write to lianne@pandan.com.
Lianne

· As a specialist dive tour operator, may I suggest the Caribbean Dutch Antillean island of Bonaire - located in the southern Caribbean (out of the hurricane paths) and just north of the Venezuelan coast.

It is easily reached from most regional UK airports on KLM via Amsterdam with prices starting from around £787 including flights, transfers, and seven nights' accommodation. Half board is an extra £34pp per day. A learn-to-dive Professional Association of Diving Instructors (PADI) open water course costs £205pp, and for experienced divers a one-tank boat dive and unlimited shore diving is £25pp. Two-tank boat dive and unlimited shore diving is £34pp.
Robertward@harlequin-holidays.co.uk

· The Red Sea is the best place to learn to dive. It has warm, clear waters that offer good visibility and is close enough to Europe to ensure value for money. Discover Red Sea (020-7407 2111) specialises in holidays for beginners and experienced divers alike. Eilat, Dahab and Sharm-el-Sheikh all offer excellent shore diving, boat diving and PADI courses. November is a good time to go as the weather is still relatively hot. Prices lead in at £379pp staying at the Ambassador Hotel in Eilat, £349pp at the Falcon Hills in Sharm-el-Sheikh and £309pp at the Bedouin Moon in Dahab.
Emma Goodwin

· Try Scubaway (01273 746261)
Rebecca van der Putt

webTitle: Seaside temptations

fields.headline: Seaside temptations
fields.standfirst: Author  Dermot Bolger  has set his new novel in a fictitious hotel. Here he reveals its real-life model
fields.trailText: Author Dermot Bolger has set his new novel in a fictitious hotel. Here he reveals its real-life model.
fields.body:
I suspect that, at heart, novelists - except for the lucky few whose lives seem to be permanent vacations - never really take holidays. Even in our sleep we invent characters; and we loathe beaches because the sand gets into our computers.

Occasionally we submit to being dragged off to exotic hotels by long-suffering partners, but after one day of alleged relaxation our fingers start to itch. We sit seemingly half-asleep on deckchairs, while secretly studying every passing face and inventing extraordinary, clandestine and improbable lives for them.

At least that's how it seems at times. More likely it's simply the fact of escaping from day-to-day pressures that allows the most unlikely of ideas to enter our heads in hotels, be dismissed out of hand and yet still linger there long enough for us, months later, to eventually take the first tentative steps to invent a world to contain them.

Not that all hotels are the same. City hotels, by their nature, are transient stopovers, impersonal places that guests shoot through and forget. A novelist published in several languages spends part of their life being shunted around such places, with nothing to distinguish them in their memory except the different shapes of tiny bottles of stolen shower gel found stowed away in their bag months later.

You give a reading at eight o'clock in the evening, return to your hotel at 10, retire at midnight, lie awake listening to the clanging lift-shaft, the wheezing central-heating, the chorus of televisions and the guest next door who sounds like he's trying to share a shower with a highly strung Irish wolfhound. Then, around 2am you turn the light back on and grievously assault the mini-bar.

This type of hotel fascinated me enough to devise Finbar's Hotel and Ladies Night at Finbar's Hotel and cajole/bully a legion of Irish writers to lend their imaginations to a collective writing experience in two different volumes. The bizarre events conjured by the writers in both books testify to the nature of city hotels.

You might think my fascination with hotels would be sated by now, but a different, relaxing type of hotel experience has, over the past seven years, gradually crystallised in my mind into the apparently quiet family holiday at the heart of my new novel, Temptation.

Without the introduction of the concrete block in 1902, not only would my annual holiday - along with generations of Irish families - be less interesting, but Temptation would never have been inspired and written.

Although William J. Kelly applied in 1893 for a licence to build a hotel on Rosslare Strand in Wexford, all he initially constructed - in the then wildness of sand dunes - was a small wooden tea-rooms. Hardly enough to keep a growing family, which is why he also ran a brick-building enterprise, which traded successfully until the concrete block knocked the foundations out of his trade in 1902. A lesser man might have strapped a quantity of unsold bricks to his back and drowned himself. Instead Mr Kelly simply knocked down his wooden tea-rooms and used his unwanted bricks to build a proper hotel, therefore founding a legendary Irish hotel dynasty.

The legend grew as his son, the keen photographer and bird-watcher, Nicholas, took over in the 1920s; to be succeeded in the 1950s by Billy and Breda Kelly (who awarded certificates in winter to anybody crazy enough to run straight from the sauna down into the icy waves); and who were, in turn, followed by Bill and Isabelle Kelly, who run it today.

If this succession suggests a continuity, then the loyalty of guests compounds the sensation. Ending my first stay I thought the queue to pay was moving slowly until I discovered that most guests were not just paying their bill, but booking themselves in for the same week next year.

Continuity fascinates a writer almost as much as change does, possibly because it can provide the medium to measure and compare change. Over the years as I returned to Kelly's Hotel I found myself becoming increasingly conscious of the changes in my own life since I was last there, from the time I had to eat my meals with one hand holding down a screaming child in a high-chair, to now when my children wander freely by themselves.

These dichotomies and the sense of a life passing must be far more pronounced for people who have been returning there for 40 or 50 years. But each year, as I walked in its gardens or rambling corridors with its famous art collection, I felt that a novel was waiting to be set within its walls, until I was eventually seduced by the temptation to write it.

In recent years there seems an unspoken competition among Irish novelists to further push back the bounds of shockability in Irish fiction. As somebody who helped to set the ball rolling with a government minister defecating on an Irish emigrant in a hotel bedroom in The Journey Home, I'm hardly blameless here, and I believe it to be invigorating that everything within the bounds of human experience should fall within the ambit of fiction.

You see this curve in French film also to such an extent that you can virtually date most French films between 1965 and 1974 by their level of sexual explicitness. Yet one of the most interesting and erotic French films of this period is Claire's Knee, where the sole physical contact occurs when a man briefly touches the knee of the woman he is infatuated with.

If the film Night on Earth inspired Finbar's Hotel, then Claire's Knee inspired Temptation. In my previous novels characters' lives were transformed by major, often brutal, political or social events. But in Temptation I wanted to explore the life of a seemingly happily married woman enjoying what seems on the surface to be a normal family holiday. Yet by the end of it, without even her husband knowing, her life is utterly transformed. I began the novel proper the week after my 40th birthday when I realised that lots of events, which still seemed vivid and immediate to me, had now in fact occurred 20 years before. It was a sobering thought and one which haunts the character Alison Gill, who has returned to the same hotel with her husband and children every year, unaware that the man she almost married 20 years before has done the same with his family during a different week.

Following the death of his wife and children in a crash he returns for one last visit, accidentally stumbling into Alison just as her husband is forced to return home on business, abandoning her there with the children.

I wanted them to meet when she was feeling most insecure, so that she found herself being forced to sit in judgment on her own life: her present-day reality versus her image at 18, which he had carried in his heart.

Perhaps only somebody who has not seen us for 20 years can truly judge how our body and spirit has withstood two decades of living. In Alison, I wanted to explore how a mother feels trapped by always having to curb her own needs to mind her children; how somebody can love their husband but became aware of the phantom pain of unfinished business; how the touch you always ache for is the one you've never known.

Last year I locked myself away during daylight hours on a remote lighthouse to complete Temptation. Seagulls were my company, a seal sunbathing on a rock below my window at low tide, the occasional stray fisherman.

I wrote through a woman's voice, because women are able to treat their emotions more openly. What fascinated me was the challenge of creating a holiday that, on the surface, appeared an exact replica of every other holiday there. The same routine of meals and swims, with, underneath that smooth rhythm, a turmoil that nobody present could conceive of.

Writers being compulsive liars, I sat down after finishing it to remove the real life location from it and make it totally unrecognisable. Then I stopped myself. Re-reading it I found that - although the characters were completely fictitious - I had used every corridor and rock and tree in the hotel.

Why not keep it like that, I thought, and create a work of fiction that readers could physically move around within, recognise the rooms and paintings and even play the same golf holes? Why not play with fiction by leaving a record of how a real building felt at one moment in time?

I did change the hotel's name to Fitzgerald's and the owner's name to anything except "William J". Kelly's Hotel is real and Fitzgerald's a work of fiction. But next time I return there I'll keep turning corners and expect to see the clandestine imaginary couple whose thoughts, regrets and temptations populated my days on a remote lighthouse near Dublin, keeping me company along with the seagulls, the basking seal and the occasional stray fisherman.

The practicals

Five-day midweek breaks at Kelly's Resort Hotel, Rosslare, Co Wexford (00353 53 32114, fax: +53 32222, e-mail: kellyhot@iol.ie, web: www.kellys.ie) cost from I£355pp based on two sharing, two-day weekends from I£180. British Airways (0845 7733377, www.britishairways.co.uk) to Dublin from £88.80 including tax; Ryanair (0870 1569569, www.ryanair.com) from £58.80. Hertz rental car (0870 599 6699 www.hertz.co.uk) from I£160.25 per week. Take the N11 motoway from Dublin to Rosslare.

 Dermot Bolger's novel, Temptation, is published by Flamingo.

Perhaps only somebody who has not seen us for 20 years can truly judge how our body and spirit has withstood two decades of living. In Alison, I wanted to explore how a mother feels trapped by always having to curb her own needs to mind her children; how somebody can love their husband but became aware of the phantom pain of unfinished business; how the touch you always ache for is the one you've never known. Last year I locked myself away during daylight hours on a remote lighthouse to complete Temptation. Seagulls were my company, a seal sunbathing on a rock below my window at low tide, the occasional stray fisherman. I wrote through a woman's voice, because women are able to treat their emotions more openly. What fascinated me was the challenge of creating a holiday that, on the surface, appeared an exact replica of every other holiday there. The same routine of meals and swims, with, underneath that smooth rhythm, a turmoil that nobody present could conceive of. Writers being compulsive liars, I sat down after finishing it to remove the real life location from it and make it totally unrecognisable. Then I stopped myself. Re-reading it I found that - although the characters were completely fictitious - I had used every corridor and rock and tree in the hotel. Why not keep it like that, I thought, and create a work of fiction that readers could physically move around within, recognise the rooms and paintings and even play the same golf holes? Why not play with fiction by leaving a record of how a real building felt at one moment in time? I did change the hotel's name to Fitzgerald's and the owner's name to anything except "William J". Kelly's Hotel is real and Fitzgerald's a work of fiction. But next time I return there I'll keep turning corners and expect to see the clandestine imaginary couple whose thoughts, regrets and temptations populated my days on a remote lighthouse near Dublin, keeping me company along with the seagulls, the basking seal and the occasional stray fisherman. webTitle: Book of the week

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: The Traveller's Healthbook (Wexas, £7.50)
fields.trailText: The Traveller's Healthbook
fields.body:
At first sight, this book will put you off travelling for life.

As it says in the introduction, whether you are going to the ski-slopes or the beach or a backpacker hostel, there is something in here that could scare you to death - malaria, rabies, diarrhoea, bilharzia (don't ask), snake bites or scorpions.

But then in witty style this book tells you everything you ever need to know (and some things you might prefer not to know) about staying healthy while travelling abroad.

With sections on travel stress, culture shock, jet lag, flying in comfort, and sex (HIV infection from having sex abroad is the single most frequent cause of lethal infection in travellers), you should be just about able to get home unscathed.

Make sure you don't leave home without it.

webTitle: 1,000 Mile socks

fields.headline: 1,000 Mile socks
fields.trailText: A sock within a sock.
fields.body:
What is it? A sock within a sock.

Don't be gnomic. The inner layer stays with the foot, the outer layer moves with the shoe.

So? Friction on the skin is eliminated and wear is reduced.

Meaning? You don't get blisters and they last a 1,000 miles.

Can this be true? That's what the guarantee says from 1,000 Mile Sportswear.

Do they quibble? No, in fact they give three or four refunds a week. But that figure hasn't risen while sales have trebled in the past four years.

What else do the socks do? Combat sweaty feet. The moisture moves naturally to the drier outside layer - especially if the inner layer is made from Tactel.

What's that? A synthetic nylon fibre that draws moisture away from the skin. You can also get them in wool, cotton and combinations thereof.

Who uses them? The first use was medical, for people with poor circulation. Then runners began using them. Now increasingly walkers and golfers are investing in a pair.

What do they cost? Between £8.99 and £12.99. There are 50 different styles and lots of colours.

Where do I get them? Specialist outdoor shops: for local stockists call 01923 242233.

Not to be confused with: The 1,000 Guineas, hundreds and thousands, thousand-island dressing.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Up to standard | Work in progress | Animal instinct
fields.body:
Up to standard
British ski instructors can now teach legally in Europe, following recognition by the French of the British Association of Snowsports Instructors qualification. The news is announced in The Good Skiing and Snowboarding Guide 2001, published this week by Which? at £15.99. To order, call 0800 252100).

Work in progress
Eurostar is is closing its Ashford International Terminal in Kent on the weekend of Saturday September 30 and Sunday October 1 due to essential engineering work. Eurostar services from London will not be affected.

Animal instinct
Pet owners crossing the channel with P&O Stena Line can now book travel insurance for their cats and dogs when they book their ferry tickets. Five-Star AA Pet Travel insurance costs £9 per pet for a trip lasting up to eight days.

Taking off
More than 30 million passengers have gone through Orlando International Airport in Florida in the past year.

Twilight zone
Virgin Holiday customers at Gatwick can now check-in the evening before they depart, so avoiding the queues. The Twilight check-in, between 3.30pm and 9pm, is available for all routes except Boston.

Net result
Over 63% of consumers believe that the internet will be the dominant technology for booking travel in five years' time, according to an online travel survey by Anite Travel Systems. Most respondents said they would prefer to book with an established travel company rather than a dotcom. Men make the majority of online travel booking, unlike in traditional "leisure bookings".

Welcome break
STA Travel has produced a booklet called Year Out, which contains information for students taking a break from their studies. STA Travel found that of 3,000 university applicants, 83% said that they were taking a year out. For a copy of the booklet, call 020-7361 6166.

Overseas aid
The Winston Churchill Memorial Trust are offering around 100 British men and women of any age the chance to conduct projects overseas with their Travelling Fellowships. Details and application forms are on www.wcmt.org.uk or send a SAE to The Winston Churchill Memorial Trust, 15 Queen's Gate Terrace, London SW7 5PR. The closing date is October 24.

webTitle: Shopping in... Malaysia

fields.headline: Shopping in... Malaysia
fields.trailText: "Over here, over here, you want Calvin Klein T-shirt?" beckoned the fifth salesman in a row. "All genuine fakes," he added for good measure.
fields.body:
"Over here, over here, you want Calvin Klein T-shirt? DKNY jeans? Tommy Hilfiger sweatshirt?," beckoned the fifth salesman in a row. "All genuine fakes," he added for good measure.

We were perusing the wares displayed on stall after stall in the night market - known locally as Thieves Market - on the Malaysian island of Penang. And, it has to be said, the fakes really were as genuine as they come.

While the starting price for most of the clothes on offer was between £10 and £15 - cheap at twice the price - bartering was positively encouraged. In fact one vendor, perplexed by our Western reluctance to haggle, started the bidding for us - talking himself down to final asking prices of somewhere between £5 and £8. The Thieves Market is ideal for anyone who wants cut-price anything, from hand-carved religious effigies to encyclopedias. But the stalls attracting the largest crowds by some margin were those selling compact discs at £1.80 each.

We bought the greatest hits of everyone from The Police through Madonna, Barry White and Bob Marley - 10 cds for just £18. It was the second leg of a week-long visit to Malaysia which began in the capital, Kuala Lumpur, a shopper's paradise with 24 malls and department stores. We were there for the first ever August Mega Sale Carnival, which began on August 5 and marked the start of two weeks during which prices in shops throughout the country were reduced by up to 70%. The Mega Sale is to be a thrice-yearly event which the Malaysian Tourist Board hopes will be an extra incentive for people to visit and shop.

The most popular of KL's shopping complexes is the Sungai Wang Plaza, home to more than 500 shops selling everything from fashion to electronic goods. If you don't have your heart set on a specific brand name, you could save up to £200 on the more pricy electrical equipment. But our search for an Apple McIntosh iMac laptop computer was less rewarding as the £1,000 price tags mirrored those at home.

Video compact discs were less than £2 a throw. Lot 10, which is linked to BB Plaza by an overhead bridge, is one of the best places to find good value watches and cosmetics. For the label-conscious, the Star Hill shopping centre boasts outlets selling gear by a host of European designers - though don't expect to snap up any big bargains: the authentic stuff rarely comes cheap. However, a price tag of £100 on a pair of Calvin Klein sunglasses was quickly slashed to £60 when I expressed interest - with an offer of even further reductions when I failed to bite.

Gems are duty-free and can be picked up at two-thirds the price in the UK. A pair of 18-carat-gold sapphire earrings would set you back £154, an 18-carat-gold ring with five diamonds £356, a white-gold ring with single marquise diamond £1,000 and a huge yellow sapphire with diamond surround ring £2,200.

When you're tired and hot, there are endless cafés and restaurants where two people can enjoy a big lunch or dinner - Malaysian, Chinese or Indian - and a couple of Tiger beers for as little as £6. The tables outside the Blues Café (it's hard to find a restaurant or bar without a Western name) on Jalan Sultan Ismail, near Lot 10 shopping centre are a good place to relax.

BA flies to Kuala Lumpur from London Heathrow for £1,385.30 including tax, Virgin £535 including tax, Malaysian Airlines (020-7341 2040) £604.30 including tax.

webTitle: Shopping in... Delhi

fields.headline: Shopping in... Delhi
fields.trailText: This is a fantastic place to shop. Many items are available at a fraction of what they would cost in the UK.
fields.body:
This is a fantastic place to shop. Many items are available at a fraction of what they would cost in the UK. While haggling in India can be stressful, there are several government emporia that sell goods from across the subcontinent at a fixed price. And there are also some excellent restaurants and swimming pools where you can relax afterwards.

Bear in mind that Delhi is extremely hot in the summer months (May-July), though the monsoon, which has just arrived, brings some relief.

Probably the top place to shop is Fabindia in Greater Kailash (646 5497), which exports much of its stock to the Conran Shop. Fabindia sells cool and classically-tailored Indian clothing, as well as some household goods. Prices are terrific: a pure silk dress with trousers costs £22, a striped cotton dressing gown £5, a man's silk shirt £11, cotton print dress £5.50, and scarf £1.50. You can buy carpets here, too. A handwoven cotton carpet will set you back £20-£45, while you can pick up an orange wool carpet for a mere £12.

Over in Connaught Place, the modern hub of New Delhi, is the Central Cottage Industries Emporium (332 0439), a rambling six-storey government shop where you can buy anything from a 12ft ornamental elephant god to a packet of Darjeeling tea. Prices are clearly displayed and fixed. This is a good place to buy gifts for friends at home. You can pick up a pure pashmina shawl for £150, while a pashmina/silk mix costs £50. There is a jewellery section (ornamental earrings £2.50, chunky silver necklace £30-£50), as well as a floor full of children's toys (shiny two-inch elephant 60p). The emporium will ship purchases home for you: up to 20kg by sea costs around £15.

Nearby are several other state emporia: the Jammu and Kashmir Emporium has good carpets and shawls. Over at Connaught Circus, the government-run Khadi Gramodyog Bhavan (336 0902) offers comfortable kurta pyjamas (£3) and Nehru jackets (£5) made from khadi, the homespun cloth promoted by Gandhi (whose garlanded portrait adorns the entrance). The United Coffee Shop five minutes' walk away is a pleasant air-conditioned refuge: it serves espresso, as well as Indian and continental food.

Over at Sarojini Market near Chanakyapuri, Delhi's diplomatic quarter, there is a range of shops where you can buy cheap high-street label clothes (eg baby Gap top 50p, dress £2). The more up-market Santushti Shopping Complex a short cab ride away also sells silks and pashminas as well as jewellery. Its Basil and Thyme restaurant is a favourite hang-out of Delhi's political elite and serves good risotto and pasta. Three minutes away is the state-run Hotel Samrat, where non-residents can take a dip in the uncrowded pool for £2.80. There is a children's pool here too.

For the classically chaotic Indian shopping experience, head for the warren of bazaars near the Red Fort in Old Delhi. You can buy anything here from car parts to carpets. Be prepared to haggle. By contrast Dilli Haat, in south west Delhi, is a peaceful village-style craft market where you can sample food from all over India at open-air stalls. India is also a very good source of cheap books. One of the city's best bookshops is Bahri and Sons (469 4610) in Khan market, a central shopping alley popular with expats.

BA flies direct from London to Delhi from £595, Air India (020-7495 7950) flies the same route for £939 inclu tax, and Virgin from £580 including tax. Direct flights between India and the UK are almost always full and it is advisable to book well in advance.

Prices are terrific: a pure silk dress with trousers costs £22, a striped cotton dressing gown £5, a man's silk shirt £11, cotton print dress £5.50, and scarf £1.50. You can buy carpets here, too. A handwoven cotton carpet will set you back £20-£45, while you can pick up an orange wool carpet for a mere £12. Over in Connaught Place, the modern hub of New Delhi, is the Central Cottage Industries Emporium (332 0439), a rambling six-storey government shop where you can buy anything from a 12ft ornamental elephant god to a packet of Darjeeling tea. Prices are clearly displayed and fixed. This is a good place to buy gifts for friends at home. You can pick up a pure pashmina shawl for £150, while a pashmina/silk mix costs £50. There is a jewellery section (ornamental earrings £2.50, chunky silver necklace £30-£50), as well as a floor full of children's toys (shiny two-inch elephant 60p). The emporium will ship purchases home for you: up to 20kg by sea costs around £15. Nearby are several other state emporia: the Jammu and Kashmir Emporium has good carpets and shawls. Over at Connaught Circus, the government-run Khadi Gramodyog Bhavan (336 0902) offers comfortable kurta pyjamas (£3) and Nehru jackets (£5) made from khadi, the homespun cloth promoted by Gandhi (whose garlanded portrait adorns the entrance). The United Coffee Shop five minutes' walk away is a pleasant air-conditioned refuge: it serves espresso, as well as Indian and continental food. Over at Sarojini Market near Chanakyapuri, Delhi's diplomatic quarter, there is a range of shops where you can buy cheap high-street label clothes (eg baby Gap top 50p, dress £2). The more up-market Santushti Shopping Complex a short cab ride away also sells silks and pashminas as well as jewellery. Its Basil and Thyme restaurant is a favourite hang-out of Delhi's political elite and serves good risotto and pasta. Three minutes away is the state-run Hotel Samrat, where non-residents can take a dip in the uncrowded pool for £2.80. There is a children's pool here too. For the classically chaotic Indian shopping experience, head for the warren of bazaars near the Red Fort in Old Delhi. You can buy anything here from car parts to carpets. Be prepared to haggle. By contrast Dilli Haat, in south west Delhi, is a peaceful village-style craft market where you can sample food from all over India at open-air stalls. India is also a very good source of cheap books. One of the city's best bookshops is Bahri and Sons (469 4610) in Khan market, a central shopping alley popular with expats. BA flies direct from London to Delhi from £595, Air India (020-7495 7950) flies the same route for £939 inclu tax, and Virgin from £580 including tax. Direct flights between India and the UK are almost always full and it is advisable to book well in advance.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Norfolk Island

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Norfolk Island
fields.standfirst: Colleen McCullough
fields.trailText: Colleen McCullough
fields.body:
Why: It is where I have lived for 20 years and because I met my husband, a native Norfolk Islander, there.

The island is an old volcano, very hilly and surrounded by magnificent cliffs. It is heavily forested with the native Norfolk Island pine and, although it's sub-tropical, it looks Arctic because of the pine. When you look under the pines you see all the tropical trappings such as palms and bananas.

It is the best place to snorkel I've ever been: the coral reef is only 100 yards from the shore so you can paddle out in your flippers.

Even though it is a tourist resort, it is absolutely peaceful. It is three by five miles and sits all on its own in an infinity of ocean between the tip of the north island of New Zealand and New Caledonia. There is no town, only a shopping centre, but you know everyone you want to know, and we all know far too much about one another.

Yet because it is so hilly and the roads are so winding, you don't get a sense of how small and isolated it is unless you go up to the top of the mountain and look out to the water all around you. Despite living there for 20 years, there are still places I haven't been to.

What's the best thing? There is no pressure on anyone; you feel isolated because you are isolated. You are in an enclosed world, beautiful and different.

My advice: I'd hire a car, because it is too hilly to walk and just pootle around the island enjoying that sense of isolation.

How do I get there? Air New Zealand (020-8741 2299) flies London to Norfolk Island return via Auckland or Christchurch plus a stopover in Los Angeles for £968.10 inclu tax. For other flights and accommodation, see www.pi-travel.co.nz/norfolk_island.

 Morgan's Run by Colleen McCullough is published by Century at £17.99.

webTitle: Somewhere in Britain

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Surrey stroll | Middle-age spread | Going fission
fields.body:
Surrey stroll
Choose from more than 20 guided walks for all levels in the Guildford area, four to 21 miles in length. Heritage and historical themes vary, from wine making to Jane Austen. Sat/Sun. Phone 01483 444333 for a programme to register. £10 fee includes free shuttle bus to starting point at Burchatts Farm Barn, Stoke Park, Guildford, Surrey.

Middle-age spread
Fifteenth-century England is revisited in a new festival village at Warwick. Minstrels, working blacksmiths and knights on horseback. Sat/Sun, 10am-6pm. £10.95/£6.50, under 4s free, family £29. Warwick Castle, Warwick (01926 406600).

Going fission
Any atom-splitting questions can be answered for children at Sellafield Visitors Centre. The walk-in model of a power station, global pollution displays and mock-up of a nuclear reactor make the day go with a bang. Open daily 10am-5pm. Free. Seascale, Cumbria (01946 727027).

Autumn leaves
Not potted your bulbs yet? The Great Autumn Plant Fair at the National Trust's Beningbrough Hall will help. Sun 11am-4pm. £3.50/£1.70/family £8.70. NT members £1.20. Shipton-by-Beningbrough, Yorkshire (01904 470666).

Wales on canvas
The best works by Welsh artists are here, from 1900 to the present day, priced from £200. Open Mon-Sat, 10am-4pm. Free. The Museum of Modern Art, Heol Penrallt, Machynlleth, Powys (01654-703355).

Sea airs
Festival activities around Seahouses fishing harbour include dancing, singing, Northumberland piping, a performance of shanties by the local fishermen's choir, a children's walking procession and various seafood tastings. Sat/Sun, times and venues vary. Free. The Harbour, Seahouses, Northumberland (01289 301864).

Green power
Nature's World offers two major sustainable development projects - an eco-structure that's earth-sheltered using geothermal heating, and an indoor bowl-shaped garden known as a hydroponicum which grows fruits, flowers and herbs without soil. Open daily 10am-5pm (Suns6pm). £3.50/£1.50/family £8.50. Ladgate Lane, Acklam, Middlesborough (01642 594895).

West End world
London's first Regent Street Festival will see the road closed to traffic for the first time, making way for celebrity presenters, pop groups such as Steps, performances from West End musicals and a funfair. Sun, noon-8pm. Free. Regent Street, London W1 (020-7491 4429).

webTitle: Shopping in... New York

fields.headline: Shopping in... New York
fields.trailText: Shopping in New York is an unmitigated pleasure. Those short of time should concentrate on three general areas: midtown, downtown and discount.
fields.body:
Shopping in New York is an unmitigated pleasure. Those short of time should concentrate on three general areas: midtown, downtown and discount.

A midtown extravaganza should start with the star-spangled department store experience at Saks on 49th and Fifth (212 753 4000). Wander up Fifth to gaze into Bergdorf Goodman (212 753 7300) and Audrey Hepburn's Tiffany's for sheer window shopping joy.

Men with a fetish for continental European style at American prices love Faconnable on 5th and 54th while women can shop for Manolos before popping next door to St Patrick's Cathedral to atone for the sin of such shoe shopping.

Turn right on Fifth at 60th street towards Madison Avenue and Barneys (212 826 8900) for cosmetics and upmarket prices. Nicole Farhi opened last year opposite DKNY but remember that European brands are almost always more expensive in the US.

After a day of midtown shopping, head for the bar at the top of the Peninsular Hotel (55th and Fifth) for a drink with a view or go to the wonderful Grand Central station to recover.

Downtown shopping provides a more varied retail experience. SoHo, below Houston Street between 6th and Broadway, is worth exploring as is Canal Street for cheap jeans. Fifth Avenue below 23rd Street is also good for basics and branches of Banana Republic, Club Monaco, Gap and J Crew.

Trendier than either of these areas is Nolita, or North of Little Italy, where you can buy great things from Tracey Feith dresses to Tin Tin paraphernalia. Start north of Houston and wander south through Mott, Elizabeth and Mulberry streets.

End a shopping day downtown by heading to Union Square and its various watering holes. If your legs still work, visit Paragon sports on Broadway at 18th, a mecca for all sports goods.

Dedicated bargain hunters with a day to spare head for Woodbury Common, the ne plus ultra of discount outlets. Some 220 designer discount shops are reached on a 50-minute bus ride upstate.

Contact Gray Line Tours (212 397 2620) for details of buses that leave the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Otherwise, combine the World Trade Centre with a trip to the bargain basement of Century 21.

British Airways (0845 7733377) flies Gatwick-JFK return for £278.90 inclu tax. Virgin Atlantic (01293 511 581) flies Gatwick to Newark return for £278.60 including tax.
