The International Olympic Committee has not fussed itself with funding scientific research, so there is no test. The cheats can smirk their way to the podium. I agree with you; the majority of athletes are not drug fuelled  but they cant all win golds. Only a few can and youll know the common view in the athletics community that many of the elite performers are using drugs. They will be the role models for the youngsters who will flock to the national athletics stadium. To be honest, Im already weeping into my ale. All the best, Andrew Dear Andrew, Weve never met but Im a bit worried about your alcohol consumption. Id hate to think you use beer as a performance enhancer for your writing! Youre right that our dream is identical  to be inspired by honest Olympian endeavour. Its our expectations that differ. The extra safeguards in Sydney are impressive and it would be wonderful if a proportion of the incredible wealth generated by the games could be spent on improved education and quality research into better testing. But I do think attitudes are changing and can continue to change. Sport reflects society as it is and not as it used to be (or necessarily as we wish it ideally would be). But much as fashions change, ideology can make a comeback, with the result that we could well be sitting in our new national athletics stadium in 2012, 2016 or 2020, saying: The Olympic ideal flickered, was almost extinguished, yet somehow survived. One has to imagine that possibility because the alternative is to give up on the hope offered by sporting integrity and admit defeat. Isnt it? Lets enjoy Sydney with an attitude of tempered optimism. But on the off-chance Im wrong, Im off down the pub now. Keep up the good work. Cheers, David TARGET="_NEW">www.ukathletics.org TARGET="_NEW">www.olympics.org.uk

webTitle: Face to Faith: A way to heal the Balkan wound

fields.headline: A way to heal the Balkan wound
fields.trailText: Since the end of the war in 1995, Bosnia has achieved some sort of stability, thanks to $5bn in aid, the work of many international organisations and the establishment of the office of the High Representative, which is bringing about a discreet style of colonial rule for this hybrid state: half protectorate, half partition.
fields.body:
Since the end of the war in 1995, Bosnia has achieved some sort of stability, thanks to $5bn in aid, the work of many international organisations and the establishment of the office of the High Representative, which is bringing about a discreet style of colonial rule for this hybrid state: half protectorate, half partition.

But there is little evidence of spiritual reconstruction, at least not in two regions I have visited: Western Bosnia centring on Bihac, and in Banja Luka, the "capital" of the Bosnian Serb half of the Federation.

The minorities in these regions suffer. The Orthodox and Catholic communities in Western Bosnia have been devastated. Twenty-six Orthodox churches in the Bihac area have been destroyed. In the Catholic diocese of Banja Luka, only a few elderly Catholics remain.

In spite of countless appeals to every international forum, the return of minorities to their homes is obstructed. Basic human rights are non-existent - the right to one's home, to work, to education and healthcare, and the freedom of worship. Given these realities, it may seem an indulgence to speak of the need for spiritual reconstruction.

Without it, the prospects are bleak. Spiritual reconstruction is the long, difficult and time-consuming process of reconciliation and healing so that enough confidence and trust can be generated for different communities to live together. This process is not the same as the mediation of skilled negotiators who anticipate mutual concessions resulting in compromises. Such mediation is an ingredient of the political peace process, but it is not the same as reconciliation.

Reconciliation first has to take account of the victim. It is the victim and not the perpetrator of the crime who initiates it. But how can peace be made with another person when one of the parties does not accept guilt? In Bosnia, this process is made even more complicated by the sometimes unbearable immediacy of past events, not only those of the last decade, but historical events going back centuries. Memories of massacres and destruction, a sense of martyrdom, of being forgotten and misunderstood by all sides haunt the religion and scar the psyches of a generation of middle-aged and of elderly people.

But there is also a longing for change, a new attitude. Bosnia wants to be part of Europe. Young people's fastidious attention to appearance implies that they are turning their back on the conflicts which preoccupied the older generations. The culture of the young owes more to western fashion and popular music than to the obligation of Friday prayers or attendance at Sunday worship. The contrast of these well-groomed, poised and confident young people with the patriarchal, medieval mind set of Islam and western and eastern Christianity is striking and inescapable.

The war may have represented the death throes of corrupt totalitarianism. The old guard, once high-ranking communists climbing the ladder as the system collapsed, turned to militant nationalism and held on to power by inflaming ethnic hatreds. Once they have gone, the new generation has the opportunity to build a more tolerant society, provided the importance of the process of spiritual reconstruction is recognised.

There are opportunities for bold and enduring actions that will build trust and confidence between former enemies. Religion has much to offer, although we know how religion can exacerbate conflict, particularly when the identity of a community is threatened. But religion is rarely the cause of conflict. At their best, all the great religions share fundamental values: compassion, a sense of the sacredness of creation, an affirmation of the dignity of every person, of justice and the offering of hospitality to the stranger.

This is where I hope that the Soul of Europe project can come in. It is a new ecumenical interfaith venture to establish a network of projects across the continent to promote justice, a tolerant spirit and solidarity with those who are not consulted.

Now is the time, not just for dialogue between religions, but for the major religious traditions to work together to build that society which honours those values, however imperfectly, drawing on the inspiration and idealism of the younger European generation.

In Banja Luka during the war, 16 mosques were destroyed, the ruins bulldozed and the rubble removed. Repeated requests to rebuild at least one mosque have been ignored. But were international pressure to be put on the authorities to change their minds, a great and highly charged symbolic opportunity would present itself.

Muslims, Jews, Christians, Buddhists, Hindus and young people of every persuasion could be invited from all over Europe to assist in the rebuilding of the Ferkhadija mosque, one of the jewels of Muslim architecture. This collaborative act of rebuilding, mirrored in the similar resurrection of a ruined Orthodox church and Catholic church, would be the seed for peace-making and living together as good neighbours, not only between religions, but throughout the Balkans and all Europe. Such an opportunity for transformation and renewal should not be missed.

webTitle: Kayaking in Idaho

fields.headline: Soak up the atmosphere
fields.standfirst: Wet through and loving it,  Alf Alderson pits his kayak against the rapids on the Salmon River
fields.trailText: Wet through and loving it, Alf Alderson pits his kayak against the rapids on the Salmon River.
fields.body:
Idaho seems to do a good job of keeping its natural treasures hidden from the rest of the world. Who would think, for instance, that the Potato State has more officially-designated Wilderness Areas than anywhere else in the US outside of Alaska?

The Middle Fork of the Salmon River flows right through the centre of one of these, the Frank Church - River of No Return Wilderness Area. It ranks high among white-water rafters and kayakers, not so much for the ferocity of its rapids or the difficulty of negotiating them as for the constant and regular flow of the water throughout its 100-mile length - there are very few areas of slack water. Then there's the huge variety of scenery and wildlife you encounter as you descend from the "put-in" point at 6,000ft-high Boundary Creek to the "take out", 3,000ft below at the confluence with the main Salmon.

The relative lack of really serious white-water means that the river is accessible to pretty much anyone with a sense of adventure - I was on a six-day trip with a group of Texans all of whom were the wrong side of 40, and all of whom had a great time.

At the put-in point, the Middle Fork would be unlikely to get anyone too excited - generally narrow and shallow, this is not the kind of whitewater maelstrom you see on all the raft ing posters. What you get instead is inspiring mountain scenery on either side of the river. Even in July, there are snow patches on the highest of the peaks, which rise up to between 7,000ft and 9,000ft, and you may spot any number of wild creatures ambling along the river banks, including black bears, deer, elk, big horn sheep, and, if you're really lucky, cougars, grizzlies and wolves.

The upper part of the river is quite mellow, and there are plenty of opportunities to sit back in your raft and watch the landscape drift by, or hang a line over the side and wait for a salmon or trout to bite (although being a Wilderness Area, all fish are taken on a catch-and-release basis). At the first campsite, you realise just how serious the practice of "pack it in, pack it out" is in the wilderness, applying to human waste and toothpaste spit as well as the more usual detritus of a camping trip.

Camping is in two-person tents, with campsites invariably based on idyllic white-sand beaches beside the river, with a backdrop of pine forests and blue mountains. Meals, cooked by the guides, are also excellent and varied, there's plenty of beer and wine, and it doesn't take long to crash out to the sound of the nearby current.

That said, if you take a hike from the camp-site up the canyon sides, there's every chance of seeing a big-horn sheep or deer, less so a bear (it pays to be "bear aware" if you're heading out into the back country). Ironically, it's perhaps on a lone hike before the evening meal that you're most likely to get a feel for the isolation and challenge that this landscape provided for the pioneers who stumbled through here less than 100 years ago.

Away from the chatter and clatter of the camp-site, looking at the river flowing ceaselessly towards the far distant Pacific Ocean and the peaks and forests bearing down from above, it's not hard to imagine the awesome and sometimes frightening beauty that Idaho presented to those early travellers. Nor is it hard to understand why the native Sheepeater Indians, whose pictographs you may stumble across, revered and worshipped such an uncompromising and elemental landscape.

Back on the river, it wasn't until day three of the trip that white-water started to become a regular thing, and I flipped out of my "ducky" (a single-person inflatable kayak) at the first sign of turbulence. But, as more and more Class III rapids assaulted us, I was surprised at how easy they were to deal with if you follow the river guide's advice. On day four, we hit our first Class III/IV rapids. One of them, Redside, is regarded as one of the 50 classic rapids in the US, so it was with no small measure of trepidation that I approached it alone in a duckie.

All I could really see of it was a vague blur of white water and what followed was a good deal of bouncing around and a thorough soaking. Shooting a rapid of this size appears to boil down to a combination of anxiety and adrenalin, with, ideally, the adrenalin winning out and taking you through. It's only afterwards that you realise it was also fun.

It's also a sobering thought that only 30 years ago this was still pioneer territory as far as kayakers and rafters were concerned, and even today only limited numbers are allowed on the Middle Fork each year during the June-September white-water season, so you're still very much in a part of the world that relatively few others have travelled through.

The next day was different - shafts of hot sunlight beamed down from above the canyon walls to glimmer off the deep and fast flowing green waters, a noticeable change from the clear, shallow river upstream where you could see each rock beneath the surface and trout feeding on the bottom. Today's rapids would be nearly all Class III, some approaching IV, and at Devil's Tooth Rapids, I was unceremoniously flicked out of my ducky by a wave - more a solid wall of water, actually. But the swim was fun, my pride wasn't hurt, and I'd go back any time and do it again - as would every other member of our group.

And if you bear in mind that this was anything but the Red Bull generation taking on one of America's best white-water challenges, it's pretty safe to say that rafting is a sport for anyone who doesn't mind getting wet.

Getting there

The easiest way to reach the Middle Fork of the Salmon is from Boise, the capital of Idaho. Flights from the UK cost from £435 plus airport tax (North-South Travel, 01245 608291). From Boise, you can take an air taxi to the town of Stanley (from where you travel to the put-in point) then back from Salmon (the take-out point) for $195 (£135), or hire a car for the three-hour drive to Stanley. However, the car will then have to be shuttled to Salmon for you to pick up, which adds another $80 to the bill.

River guides

River Odysseys West (ROW, PO Box 579, Couer d'Alene, Idaho 83816-0579, tel: 001 208 765 0841, e-mail info@ rowinc.com), based in Couer d'Alene, organises white- water rafting trips from mid-June to mid-September, and a six-day rafting trip, including food, camping gear and transport to and from the put-in point costs $1,445 -$1,525.

Vessels provided include a sweep boat, which goes ahead each day with all the equipment to set up camp before your arrival; an oar boat, which sits high out of the water and allows you to relax while the guide controls the boat; a six-person paddle boat which requires you and fellow paddlers to do the work; and single-person inflatable kayaks, or duckies, which are easy to fall out of. You can take turns to ride in whichever of the three takes your fancy.

You can run the river independently, but a permit is required and these are limited in number and awarded by lottery.

For details on permits, contact Middle Fork Ranger District, PO Box 750 Chalis, Idaho 8326.

Where to stay

ROW arranges accommodation for the night before and after the trip in Stanley and Salmon. However, if you want something a little different, try spending your first night at the Sawtooth Hotel, Ace of Diamonds Avenue, Stanley (you won't have trouble finding it as there are only about four unpaved streets in this classic western mountain town).

Comfortable but basic rooms cost from $38 per night and staying here will have you feeling like an extra from High Plains Drifter.

Other activities

The region really is an outdoor paradise and there's enough to keep even the most energetic going for a lifetime - hiking, biking, horse riding, fishing, hunting, lounging around in the area's many hot springs.Don't expect museums, galleries and trendy coffee houses though. For more details on travelling in Idaho, contact Rocky Mountain International, PO Box 13652, London SW5 0ZR, tel: 09063 640655 (e-mail 100576.126@compuserve.com).

River classifications

Class 1: very easy

Class II: easy. Waves up to three feet; some manoeuvering required.

Class III: medium - rapids with numerous high, irregular waves capable of swamping an open canoe.

Class IV: difficult - long, difficult rapids, powerful waves, dangerous rocks, boiling eddies, constricted passages.

Class V: very difficult - long, violent rapids, which pose a significant hazard to life in the event of a mishap.

Class VI: limit of navigation - rarely run and a definite hazard to life.

webTitle: Market Place Hotel, Somerset

fields.headline: Market Place Hotel, Somerset
fields.trailText: A modest facade hides pretty 15th-century market inn and courtyard, built by a bishop for temperance purposes long since scrapped.
fields.body:
Address: Market Place Hotel, Wells, Somerset BA5 2RW
Tel: 01749 672616
Web address: www.Bhere.co.uk

First impressions: Modest facade hides pretty 15th-century market inn and courtyard, built by a bishop for temperance purposes long since scrapped.

What are the rooms like: The largest are beamy and truly spacious, with massive medieval fireplaces, authentic bumpy floors, and pleasingly light decor. For size and best outlook, try for rooms overlooking market where Judge Jeffreys held his "Bloody Assizes" after the Monmouth rebellion.

The bed test: Ample, comfortably firm mattress. Crisp cotton sheets.

The bathroom test: Large corner tub nicely fits two. Good towel supply, but slightly irksome taps.

The restaurant: Boasts two AA rosettes for its grub. Decent modern British fare using plentiful Somerset produce. Again, a nice low-key mix of medieval and modern decor.

What is there to see within walking distance? What isn't there? England's smallest village-sized city crams an architecture feast: exquisite Gothic cathedral with breathtaking west-front statuary, the best bishop's palace in the UK with battlements, moat and swans, and Europe's oldest complete medieval street.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? On one side, the Mendips, Wookey Hole caves and Cheddar gorge. On other, the Somerset levels and Glastonbury.

How much a night? From £52.50 per person per night.

Would you go back? No doubt about it.

webTitle: The Captive State by George Monbiot

fields.headline: Welcome to Britain plc
fields.standfirst:
Big business is carving up the UK. This century's defining battle will be between democracy and corporate culture, writes George Monbiot in his new revelatory new book. In our first extract, he meets islanders who are fighting American ownership of their only link to the mainland

Extract two: How big business hijacked our universities
fields.trailText: Big business is carving up the UK. This century's defining battle will be between democracy and corporate culture, writes George Monbiot in his new revelatory new book. In our first extract, he meets islanders who are fighting American ownership of their only link to the mainland
fields.body:
Britain's millennium celebrations testified to a peculiar vision of nationhood. The national beacon, lit by the Queen to kindle a chain of flame from London to Aberdeen, was a gigantic crucible on which British Gas was scored in words 11 metres long beneath a crown of 18 BG logos. The Millennium Dome exhibits the work of some of our most cherished national institutions: the American companies Manpower and Ford. Its Body Zone was sponsored by Boots, its Mind Zone by the weapons manufacturer British Aerospace, and its Learning Zone by Tesco.

Its Our Town stage, where "the diversity of local culture is celebrated", was financed by that guardian of diversity, McDonald's. British Airways and the British Airports Authority used the Journey Zone to explain to visitors the advantages of Heathrow Airport's proposed Terminal 5, in which they both have a certain interest.

At the 1999 Labour party conference, Tony Blair told delegates he would "set the people free" by creating "a model 21st-century nation, based... on the equal worth of all". But some attendees at the conference were worth rather more than others. To reach the speeches, delegates had to fight their way past 62 corporate stalls: it looked more like a trade fair than a political gathering.

The conference's fringe meeting on social justice in a global economy was sponsored by the Swiss company ABB, the builders of the turbines for the Three Gorges Dam in China, which displaced over a million people from the land. The meeting on holding government and companies to account was sponsored by the lottery company Camelot. The meeting on renewing democracy and rebuilding communities was financed by Tesco, widely blamed for shattering communities with their out-of-town superstores. When Lord Whitty, a minister at the department of the environment, was asked by the BBC whether the exhibitors at the conference were buying access to ministers, he replied: "You don't buy access to ministers. You buy access to the whole party." I think he was trying to reassure us.

They are seizing powers previously invested in government, and using them to distort public life to suit their own ends.

New Labour, its leaders often remind us, is the party of business, aiming to establish the most business-friendly environment in the world. There is, Blair told the Confederation of British Industry, "great commitment and enthusiasm, right across the government, for forging links with the business community". "We want a society," the cabinet minister Peter Mandelson announced, "that celebrates and values its business heroes as much as its pop stars and footballers."

Democracy will survive only if the people in whose name they govern rescue the state from captivity.

My story begins on the Isle of Skye, which became, under the Conservatives, the laboratory for a novel experiment. As the terms under which it is being conducted have come to light, it has developed into a scandal of the kind associated with Brazil, rather than Britain: the Labour government is now caught in this scandal.

Skye lies over the sea. This topographical distinction delights the tourists following the flight of Bonnie Prince Charlie. But by the end of the 1980s, it was a nuisance to the residents. Car ferries connecting the island to the mainland kept breaking down, so that people often had to queue for two or three hours. Some residents called for a bridge. The strait, or kyle, that separated Skye from the mainland, they argued, was scarcely a mile wide at its narrowest point. English islands close to the mainland coast were served by roads; was it not time for Skye to be connected to the national network?

The Scottish Office, a department of the Conservative government, agreed. Road building was, at the time, a central component of the government's economic programme. There was, it told the people of Skye, just one problem: it had no money. Public funds spent on building a bridge would be funds not spent on the island's health and education. Rather than be defeated by this, it had devised a new and remarkable solution.

The people of Skye would get their bridge, but it would be financed by a private company. The company would build the structure at its own expense, then recoup the money by charging a toll. The Skye Bridge would be the first project built under something called the private finance initiative (PFI). This, started by the Conservatives and developed by Labour, has become the means by which many new roads, bridges, rail links, schools, hospitals and prisons in Britain are now built.

In the week the bridge opened, in October 1995, the government-run ferry service stopped: the only efficient means of getting to Skye was the bridge. This might have been uncontroversial had the toll the private companies levied not been the highest, per metre of road, in the world. The one-mile crossing now costs £5.70 each way.

A legal discovery by veteran campaigner and folk singer Robbie the Pict convinced the people of Skye that the tolls were worth fighting. The toll regime, Robbie believed, breached Article 18 of the Act of Union, which forbids the Crown to levy a tax in Scotland in circumstances not encountered in England. As there was no sole road crossing to an inshore island which was tolled in England, and as the Scottish Office told the European Union that the tolls should be classified as a tax, the charges looked to Robbie like a violation of the act.

Convinced that they had a constitutional as well as a moral case, the islanders began one of the biggest and most sustained campaigns of civil disobedience in Scotland since the Lewis Risings of 1919. It started with a petition, circulated by the West Highland Free Press. Though Skye has only 10,000 inhabitants, within a few weeks 7,000 people had signed up, demanding a free crossing rather than a toll bridge. They were ignored. So, when the bridge opened, many of the islanders refused to pay: 600 people - crofters, shopkeepers, doctors, factory workers and engineers, most of whom had never been in trouble before - were arrested. Some collected dozens of charges: Robbie was arraigned on 129. The Highlands police and judicial systems nearly collapsed beneath the load. The islanders launched legal counter-suits.

The toll company changed its tactics. It stopped calling the police and refused to let the non-payers pass. So the islanders devised new means of frustrating their captors. Some days they would pay the toll penny by penny, blocking the bridge for hours. They would bring cardboard cheques so large that they wouldn't fit through the toll-booth window. They discovered that the collecting company banked its money on Friday, so 30 people agreed to arrive at intervals on a Saturday morning with £100 notes and no change.

I met Robbie the Pict playing football around the toll booth on the bridge in the summer of 1998. He had discovered that Hamilton Park, the land on which the toll booth and the approach road were built, had been established with a deed that only a compulsory purchase order could repeal. In its hurry to get the bridge built, the Scottish Office had initiated compulsory purchase proceedings but forgot to complete them. Legally, the land remained a designated recreation area, and Robbie and friends were lawfully entitled to play football there, and use the barrier as a goal: "They don't want to arrest us for this one as they don't want the issue raised in court. We could mount a legal challenge to the existence of the toll booths."

The islanders discovered that the company empowered by the government to collect the tolls had changed its name, while the deed which appeared to allow it to charge the money remained the same. So Robbie bought the discarded company name - Skye Bridge Tolls Ltd - and insisted that he, and not the consortium, now had the legal right to collect the money. When the company protested, he offered to sell them the original name for £1m, and demanded that they "remove our good name" from the documents they were using "for the purpose of exacting money from road users". "I've got a right," he told me, "to collect the tolls. One of these days I'm going to set up in a garden shed and if the police come I'll tell them, 'I've got the paperwork: it's them you should be arresting.'"

The protesters put in a bid to buy the bridge, and another to acquire the ferries that used to run across the kyle. Both were, unsurprisingly, rejected by the Scottish Office, which says that the bridge is owned by a consortium of three firms: two construction companies and the Bank of America. But the islanders later discovered that, by the time the bridge opened, the ownership had changed dramatically. One thousand shares had been issued. The Bank of America had 997 , while the remaining three were in the hands of Bank of America nominees. The bank was sole controller of the bridge. The other companies were employed merely to collect the tolls on its behalf and transfer the money to America. The Scottish Office had twice issued misleading statements about this.

The Bank of America, previously known as the Bank of Italy, has a blemished record. In November 1998, it settled with 250 American government agencies which had sued it, after admitting that it had improperly shifted unclaimed payments into its own accounts instead of returning them to the public bodies to which they belonged. Most islanders' tolls are transferred to the bank headquarters in California. Skye had become, according to the protesters, part of a US banking gulag, a colonial penitentiary in which they were held to ransom.

They chose Independence Day to demand release from their imperial masters. On July 4 1998, the Crofter's Kitchen cafe, on the Skye side of the bridge, was in uproar; 100 people crammed into it, singing, laughing and shouting. At the time advertised, the residents quietly filed into the car park. Robbie Cormack, a big man with a ginger moustache, brought out a clipboard. As he announced the names of the American states, protesters in fancy dress took placards: Florida went to a gigantic orange carton, with its ingredients listed as "pure Florida orange, diluted with Scottish Office mandarins". Mississippi went to a ghoul in a white hood and cape.

Other protesters took banners reading "Welcome to Skye, the £5.60 state" and "Bank of America: The bank that likes to say gimme". An accordionist struck up The Yellow Rose of Texas, and the Independence from America March set off past the sign the protesters had legally and perma nently installed on the roundabout ("Beware: bogus toll collectors ahead") and over the bridge to the mainland.

The postmaster, Drew Millar, claiming to be Bill Clinton's special representative, apologised that the president couldn't be with them: he had, regrettably "gotten held up in the bathroom, helping one of his interns to grasp the essentials of the body politic". But, he went on, "I would like to welcome you to the 51st state of America, and thank you sincerely for all the contributions you've made to our federal tax-take."

There is a sheriff's court on the island, but the Crown insisted on trying protesters (378 islanders were prosecuted) in Dingwall, 120 miles away. Because of the caseload, and the etiolated nature of sheriff's court procedures, some defendants had to turn up in court as many as 15 times to defend a single case of the non-payment of £5. "They are trying to wear us down," Robbie the Pict told me, "but they won't succeed."

Another islander, John Campbell, who trained as an engineer, looked into the financing of the project. The bridge, according to the Miller Group, which built it, cost £25m. The Scottish Office initially contributed £13m. The European Investment Bank added £13m. Private investors paid in £7.5m, the contractors £0.5m, and a commercial bank £6m: a total of £40m. The bridge was 60% overfinanced.

The only explanation the islanders could suggest is that the investors believed the bridge would make a great deal of money, and they wanted to buy into a stake. The £25m project will extract, for its private backers and the Bank of America, £88m from one of the poorest places in the British Isles.

So the people of Skye must pay a fee to an American bank every time they want to go to or from their island, although the costs of the bridge have already been met by the taxpayer and the European Investment Bank. The government had no need to use the PFI to build the bridge. As Skye lies within a regional development area, it could have asked the EU to provide nearly all the money for a toll-free crossing. The means of finance have nothing to do with saving public money. Far from Westminster and national newspapers, out of sight, out of mind, Skye was the ideal location for launching a corrupt, unpopular initiative, in which private companies were granted monopolistic control over public works.

The people of Skye had every reason to believe that a Labour government would overturn the tolls. In 1995, Brian Wilson MP, who was to become the minister for industry in the Scottish Office and, later, a minister at the department for trade and industry, described the bridge as "a shocking story of ideologues using a remote place for an experiment that they could not have got away with anywhere else". The toll regime, he announced, was "immoral, unacceptable and unjust"; while the people of Skye were the "near-monopoly prisoners of... ruthless commercial interests". In 1996, he joined the demonstrators, marching over the bridge with a pipe band, and announced that the Tartan Toll Tax was "an injustice which will not be meekly acquiesced in". In the same year, Calum MacDonald MP, now a minister in the Scottish Office, asked his opposite number: "Isn't it about time that he listened to the weight of public opinion... and scrap[ped] this toll regime?"

The local Labour candidate for the 1997 general election, Donnie Munro (formerly the lead singer of Runrig), told voters: "The Labour party is committed to work in partnership to abolish the tolls within the shortest practicable timescale." The Scottish Labour party published a full-page ad to this effect in the West Highland Free Press a week before the election.

Soon after the election was won, ministers announced that scrap ping the tolls would be impossible. It would, they maintained, cost £30m to buy out the contract, which is more than the bridge cost to design and build. Brian Wilson told Scotland on Sunday: "It's just a lie to say that either I or the Labour party promised to abolish the tolls." When the islanders requested that they be allowed to reopen the kyle ferry service and run it in competition with the bridge, Wilson told them it was a silly stunt.

"What hurts us most," John Campbell told me, "is the sense of betrayal. These ministers were campaigners before they got into power. Now they're just suits."

The Bank of America has continued to thrive in Britain. Before the election, the consortium to which it belonged won the contract to build the privately financed A30 dual carriageway in Devon. Since the election, it has become the lending bank for the £1bn PFI contract to update and operate London Transport's ticketing services.

In Skye, the court cases grind on. The islanders have now taken their appeals to the European Court of Human Rights and the European Court of Justice. But their demonstrations have diminished. Exhausted and impoverished, the people of Skye no longer have either the energy or the resources to sustain the pressure of the last few years. But they have not given up, and some say they never will. Because their battle is just the opening chapter of the corporate takeover of Britain.

 This piece is an edited extract from The Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan, £12.99)

webTitle: Self-Portrait With a Bandaged Ear, Van Gogh (1889)

fields.headline: Self-Portrait With a Bandaged Ear, Van Gogh (1889)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Vincent Van Gogh (1853-90), the definitive modern artist in that his life and work broke with traditional social bonds. In every brushstroke he seemed to express an isolated, alienated vision - the vision of, in the words of Antonin Artaud, the man suicided by society.

Subject: Van Gogh, after he cut off his own earlobe following a violent argument with fellow painter Paul Gauguin, whom he idolised and who came to stay with him in Arles in Provence in October 1888. In 1890 he shot himself.

Distinguishing features: It is hard not to feel Van Gogh's eyes pierce you when you look at this painting. His agonised, pitiful presence is almost unbearable. Every brushstroke registers physically. You can see every mark he made on the canvas and feel the weight of each dollop of blue or yellow pigment. This gives the portrait a shocking immediacy. And then there's the thin face, like Christ in a late medieval painting, with the red beard brutally shaved off. He seems to shiver inside his heavy coat and hat, with its strange fur like a black cloud emanating from his brain. In this painting, the warmth of Provence that van Gogh painted in his Sunflowers has given way to winter.

Van Gogh shows the bandage on his mutilated ear like a saint displaying the stigmata. His head is turned to give us a better view. But this is a shameful self-portrait, raw with Van Gogh's horror and acceptance of what he has done to himself. The act of self-mutilation has changed Van Gogh. He has become this walking emblem of what it is to live the life of art.

When Van Gogh went to live in the south of France in 1888 he expected to be happy. He wrote to his brother Theo that he hoped his life there would be more and more like a Japanese painter's. For late 19th-century European artists the tradi tional art of Japan represented a utopian aestheticism. But in this self-portrait the Japanese picture on the wall behind Van Gogh is a lost paradise. His own easel stands to the left, and the canvas on it is blank. It resembles what would later be called a monochrome. In that void, Van Gogh sees his own art, in contrast to the human richness of the Japanese pastoral scene.

This emptiness seeps between the fierce strokes of Van Gogh's self-portrait. In all his paintings you can often see the thin canvas just below the brushwork. Pigment builds up in rough piles, in irresistible rhythms, but always there is the sense of the space between strokes. In this painting the abstract repetition of brushstrokes is frightening. Van Gogh's coat is composed of scarily overpoweringblue lines. The yellow wall behind him has the same monotonous straight lines.

Inspirations and influences: Van Gogh's Self-Portrait With A Bandaged Ear has been echoed many times over, especially since the 1970s when the artist's body became a material for making art. In 1970 Vito Acconci squatted in an art gallery biting himself in as many places as possible in his performance Trademarks. In 1971 Chris Burden stood in an art gallery and had a friend shoot him in the arm with a rifle. He also had himself crucified and electrocuted. In every brushstroke he seemed to express an isolated, alienated vision - the vision of, in the words of Antonin Artaud, the man suicided by society. Subject: Van Gogh, after he cut off his own earlobe following a violent argument with fellow painter Paul Gauguin, whom he idolised and who came to stay with him in Arles in Provence in October 1888. In 1890 he shot himself. Distinguishing features: It is hard not to feel Van Gogh's eyes pierce you when you look at this painting. His agonised, pitiful presence is almost unbearable. Every brushstroke registers physically. You can see every mark he made on the canvas and feel the weight of each dollop of blue or yellow pigment. This gives the portrait a shocking immediacy. And then there's the thin face, like Christ in a late medieval painting, with the red beard brutally shaved off. webTitle: Meat eating questions for villagers

fields.headline: Meat eating questions for villagers
fields.trailText: Some 1,100 households in Queniborough, Leicestershire will today get questionnaires on their shopping and eating habits during the 1980s, as doctors continue investigating an apparent cluster of five victims of vCJD, the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
Some 1,100 households in Queniborough, Leicestershire will today get questionnaires on their shopping and eating habits during the 1980s, as doctors continue investigating an apparent cluster of five victims of vCJD, the human form of BSE.

Of the five, three died in 1998 and certainly had links to the village, while a 19-year-old about whom few details have been made public died this summer in Leicester, and another probable victim of the incurable disease, still alive, once lived at neighbouring Rearsby.

The questionnaires, distributed with the parish newsletter, are part of a concerted attempt to find out if the concentration of cases is significant. Inquiries might go on to December, and further questionnaires are likely.

Philip Monk, a consultant in communicable diseases, said: "We are asking whether they have children born between 1960 and 1980. Then we are asking what their shopping habits were, and where did they buy meat during the 1980s. While we are concentrating on meat, that does not mean it will end there." At a parish council meeting last month, villagers had said they wanted to do all they could to help.

Since May 1995, there have been 74 deaths in Britain, 19 so far this year, from vCJD. Eight other probable victims remain alive.

webTitle: Interview: Justin Cartwright

fields.headline: How to get ahead in novelising
fields.standfirst: Justin Cartwright tells Nicholas Wroe why the ad world failed to satisfy him
fields.trailText: Justin Cartwright tells Nicholas Wroe why the ad world failed to satisfy him
fields.body:
Justin Cartwright comes from a writing family, but he says he was never encouraged to follow in its tradition. His father was editor of the Rand Daily Mail in South Africa and a noted historian of the mining industry there. "But he used to say to people: 'Don't tell my parents I work on a newspaper,'" laughs Cartwright. "'They think I play piano in a brothel.'"

Cartwright did holiday work at the paper and, he says, "always won the essay prize at school and things like that". With no television at home, he was a voracious reader who had finished War and Peace by the time he was 15 and wrote "pretentious" plays while at school. "But I really wanted to be a filmmaker, although I ended up in advertising instead."

After university in South Africa and then Oxford, he started work for a London agency in the mid-1970s and has lived in the city ever since. His most famous campaign was for dog food. "Believe it or not, Prime Pal is for dogs" was the killer line, and Cartwright won several industry awards. He went on to make television documentaries, and is currently working on a screenplay, but says he learned little from his time in advertising.

"I suppose on the filmmaking side you can learn how to cram a lot into a small space," he says. "But I think that advertising, even on what is called the creative side, is incredibly easy if you have that kind of mind. A lot of people regard it as Machiavellian and dangerous, but in fact it is morally neutral. You are trying to sell something and the people know you are trying to sell something."

One use he did make of his ability to sell was as the man in charge of election broadcasts for the Liberal Party, and then the Alliance, at the 1979, 1983 and 1987 general elections. He says the recent complaints about the power of spin-doctors are nothing new. "Even then, it was assumed that people like me had undue influence. But the fact is that politicians are so incredibly busy they need other people to write their speeches and brief them. I don't think Alastair Campbell has any secret agenda. Most of it is reactive."

For a writer whose work is almost routinely shortlisted for major literary awards, his early efforts at fiction are perhaps surprising. He wrote a novelisation of an episode from the New Avengers, which appeared with fetching shots of Joanna Lumley and Gareth Hunt on the cover. "I didn't even read the script," he admits. "I just opened it and started to write the novel. But when I got to the end I was 30 pages short of my target length, so I made up another ending."

He then wrote two thrillers in the late 1970s which sold quite well but didn't engage him. "I wanted to do something that could be called literature. I'd done these thrillers because of an advertising frame of mind - I thought I should do something commercial rather than go with any gut feelings." He calls his next novel, Freedom of Wolves, an "interim" book, and says the real breakthrough came with the 1988 Interior. Set in an imaginary African country, it cleverly and comically subverts Conrad and Rider Haggard as the narrator, Curtiz, retraces a journey undertaken by his late father. The book was shortlisted for the Whitbread Prize.

"It didn't make much difference financially," says Cartwright, "but it helped me enormously in that it confirmed that this is what I wanted to do. It was incredibly reassuring." The book also won prizes in South Africa, and while Cartwright will "never write the great South African novel", he is still interested in literary developments there. "I thought that, post-apartheid, there would be absolutely no interest in South Africa. That has been both true and untrue. The major writers like Gordimer and Coetzee have produced major books. But some of the more minor writers have drifted away."

The follow-up to Interiors was Look at It This Way, a novel set in a fantastical London in which a lion has escaped from the zoo. It too was shortlisted for the Whitbread. Masai Dreaming in 1993 again featured Curtiz, before Cartwright returned to a London location for In Every Face I Meet, which was shortlisted for the Booker. His most recent book, Leading the Cheers, was set in America and won the Whitbread Best Novel prize in 1998. Cartwright had been an exchange student at a school in Michigan, and returned there in the mid-1990s for a reunion. "I bumped all that up for the novel," he says. "The writs haven't come in yet."

He now spends most mornings writing in the London Library, where he can find "peace and tranquillity. If I was at home I'd find myself checking email and looking at the internet when I should be working. In the library I can get an awful lot done in a couple of hours, but it can become quite sociable, which you have to watch out for. There are a lot of people you can pop out and have a coffee with."

His next novel, which will be published in January, partly draws on his political experience. A love story set in contemporary Britain, it features a spin-doctor and "a government not too dissimilar from the one in power at the moment". On his past form, we can look forward to it at least making the shortlist of the literary prizes. Cartwright, though, is more wary. "Winning the Whitbread was a very major thing for me. I'd always been well reviewed, but this made me widely read. It was a huge step up. But no doubt that puts me in the firing line for the next book."

 Look at It This Way, Masai Dreaming, Interior and In Every Face I Meet are all published by Sceptre at £6.99.

webTitle: In praise  of the  long lunch

fields.headline: In praise  of the  long lunch
fields.trailText: The objective of the Slow Food Movement isn't simply to promote long, slow lunches, or even long, slow methods of cooking, but to resist the homogenisation and globalisation of food production in all its forms.
fields.body:
In 1986, an Italian journalist called Carlo Petrini was enraged when McDonald's opened a branch in the Piazza di Spagna in Rome, the city in which he was then working. After a long, slow lunch back in his home town of Bra in Piedmont, Petrini and one or two friends decided to launch the Slow Food Movement.

The objective of the Movement isn't simply to promote long, slow lunches, or even long, slow methods of cooking, but to resist the homogenisation and globalisation of food production in all its forms. Slow Food sees food - ingredients, production, preparation, consumption - as the apotheosis of individual cultures and personal pleasure. These are threatened by the headlong rush towards a more standardised and frenetic life as personified by fast food.

The Movement now has more than 60,000 members in 35 countries, including the UK, US, France, Germany, Spain and Australia. Members are encouraged to form Convivia, in which they get together to eat, drink and discuss food matters. On a more formal basis, through the Week Of Taste, Wine Conventions, The Pleasure Game, Friendship Tables, Taste Workshops, bi-annual Hall of Taste (the third is being held in Turin, October 25-29 this year), the Slow Food Praesidia and the Ark Of Taste, the aim is to save and protect small-scale quality specialist food production from industrial standardisation and to list and protect threatened varieties of foodstuffs.

The guiding principle behind every initiative remains the right of people to the conviviality, taste and pleasure of their own culinary heritage. As Signor Petrini puts it, 'If I wear a pair of Armani underpants, they do not become a part of Carlo Petrini. If I eat a slice of ham, it becomes a part of Carlo Petrini. That is why I worry more about ham than fashion.'

 If you feel the need for a slow lunch, decent ham, or simply to protect your culinary heritage and diversity, contact Slow Food, via Mendicita, Istruita 14, 12042 Bra (CN) Italy; Tel: 00 39 0172 419 611 or 020-8744 9297; email: international@ slowfood.it

webTitle: Eating out

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort potters along by boat for a leisurely lunch in a dream hamlet
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort potters along by boat for a leisurely lunch in a dream hamlet.
fields.body:
The water chattered in companioniable fashion as it slipped beneath the bow. The outboard motor puttered with easy purpose. The day's sun refracted up off the face of the light chop in the bay. We were on our way to lunch.

The Millbrook Inn lies in the hamlet of South Pool at the tip of one of the creeks that open into Salcombe Bay in Devon. You can get to it by car. But a car, what is a car when you can get there by boat? With a boat there's no back tracking along those narrow Devon lanes to let someone past. There are no blind corners, no chuntering tractors, no nose-to-tail processions, no caravans, no hassle, bustle or fuss, only the tide to worry about.

If you don't want to walk a few hundred metres over stinking mud, then it does well to attend to the matter of tides. My brother, Tom the Navigator, calculated that we should arrive by 12noon and leave by 2pm, which is a fine natural timescale for lunch, unless you are in for a serious session, and if you have a serious session you have to be prepared to cope with the consequences, which are not as much fun as what went before.

So we took the last berth at the tiny jetty at South Pool and clambered out - Tom the Navigator, two nephews, the Daughter, and I - and pottered off into South Pool in search of the Millbrook Inn and my wife, Tom the Navigator's wife and Rosie, aged five months.

South Pool is a dream hamlet, idealised without quite being twee, a nostalgic vision, complete with winding street leading up hill to the church of St Nicholas and St Cyriac with its powerful and distinctive tower topped by the flag of St George. The 17th-century Millbrook Inn is on the same street, and is in every way as idealised as the rest, suitably cluttered, beamed and amber-lit within, with a narrow, alder-shaded terrace at the back looking out on to a small stream with white ducks and darting trout. There was beer, too, Bass from the barrel, Wadworth 6X on the pump, a short, well-priced wine list, a printed menu with dishes of the day chalked up on a blackboard.

The Millbrook is not one of the new breed of gastro-pubs. It's not in the market for fancy dishes, or even unfancy dishes, of a restaurant provenance. There's no individual assembly, no deliberate balancing of protein, veg and sauce. It caters for a different style of eating that is no less pleasurable or demanding in terms of attention to detail if it is to be done well. The food is plain and straightforward - crab salad, seafood platter, kiln-roasted salmon with dill mayonnaise, baked potato with prawns, spaghetti bolognese, tagliatelle with pesto, followed by treacle tart, apple and cider cake, sticky toffee pudding, all with clotted cream.

It may have been the sunshine winking down through the canopy of alder leaves, the chatter of the brook, the tiny trout dashing out to snatch flicked bread pellets, the pint of cool Wadworth's or the sight of folk popping their heads round the corner to look for a streamside berth and disappearing again looking disappointed, but that lunch was as satisfying as anything I've eaten this year. But then the crab salad was sweet, delicate, made with radiantly fresh local crab, and copious with it. The kiln-roasted (whatever that may mean) salmon was cold, sliced on the bias, thick as a sirloin steak , dense and full flavoured. Hugh the Nephew's judgment on the seafood platter was that it was "Gnarly, Uncle Matt." ("Do you spell that with a g or just an n, Hugh?" "Eh? Dunno.") Anyway, gnarly or narly is a superlative in the world of Hugh the Nephew.

Perhaps even more indicative that there was sense and ability at work in the kitchen was the precisely cooked pasta, a rich, beautiful and properly made bolognese sauce and a pesto, which was advertised as being made on the premises, and must have been because it tasted so cleanly and freshly of basil. I might criticise the haphazard salad assemblies - thinly sliced red cabbage has no place in a mixed salad and it is better that tomatoes are ripe rather that crunchy as apples - but at least there was no lollo rosso to rustle unpleasantly like a soggy tutu in you mouth.

There was a bit of a debate about the treacle tart, too, the children claiming that they were too sweet (eh?) and adults disagreeing profoundly as they heaved another mouthful laden with clotted cream into their mouths. I took the Epicurean option of the apple and cider cake, which was light, cidery sour and indubitably apple-y, a gnarly (or narly) piece of traditional bakery. And all the while little Rosie fed and dozed at her mother's bosom with an equanimity she wasn't showing at night.

The bill for all seven of us was £83.30, of which food was £64.25, which I will leave you to judge whether or not this was good value or not. There was time for a quick canter up to the church of St Nicholas and St Cyriac, to admire the rood screen and the medieval wagon roof and the memorial to the Rev Garren Hayman celebrated for "the integrety of his life, the Purity of his manners, his Modesty, Temperance and Affability" - Golly, I hope someone says something of the same about me when I am gone - before just beating the retreating tide to ride home with my heat of the thwarts, the water now rustling softly beneath the boat, the sunlight flickering through my closed eyes, and my daughter's head resting on my gently rounded tum.

There was time for a quick canter up to the church of St Nicholas and St Cyriac, to admire the rood screen and the medieval wagon roof and the memorial to the Rev Garren Hayman celebrated for "the integrety of his life, the Purity of his manners, his Modesty, Temperance and Affability" - Golly, I hope someone says something of the same about me when I am gone - before just beating the retreating tide to ride home with my heat of the thwarts, the water now rustling softly beneath the boat, the sunlight flickering through my closed eyes, and my daughter's head resting on my gently rounded tum.

webTitle: Christopher Lloyd: Slowing down

fields.headline: Look back in languor
fields.standfirst: Now is the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness - so ease up a bit and sit down to enjoy them, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Now is the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness - so ease up a bit and sit down to enjoy them, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
If you want to learn how to slow down in your garden, you have come to the right person. At almost 80, I have made this theme a fine art. The first essential is to get other people to do the work for you. To this end, at least one of them needs to be young and muscular and they must either be very fond of you or be well paid by you and be, overall, appreciated. And, it stands to reason, they must enjoy gardening, and you can initiate that.

It would be best, of course, to be leading from the front, teaching by example, but that is hardly a relaxing exercise, even supposing that your stamina allowed it.

There are certain times of the year and certain types of weather that make it far easier to slow down than at others. We are in one of the best right now and it will last for nearly a couple of months. Plant growth is slowing down. There is plenty of residual warmth and it is far easier to feel comfortable in the garden now than it was in spring. That is too exciting a season, change is rapid and needs to be accommodated, and there is a nasty sharpness in the air (be blowed to calling it bracing) that keeps you on the move or sends you scurrying for shelter.

Keats's Ode To Autumn, his Season Of Mists And Mellow Fruitfulness, was written (near Winchester) at just about this moment. His long strophes characterise the languid satisfaction of enjoying the moment and doing nothing. Of just being aware of pleasant surroundings. Work is needed in order to create these, if they are to be in one's own garden, but that should be something to look back on, at this moment, or that should be going on when we have not yet emerged into the open air. "I expect the pot plants will need watering, dear; they dry out much more quickly than one might expect. And, of course, the bird bath will need a clean before you fill that. And if you could dry the clothes somewhere out of sight, it does so improve the whole feel of the garden. The beans will want picking, of course, but you know all about that."

There should be satisfactions to any craving scattered through the garden. A Victora plum will be welcome just now. And a fig tree. You may need to get someone to fix bags on them to save them from the birds. The best moment to do this, as you must patiently explain, is just as a fruit is starting to colour. It will then be ripe and ready for you to eat (with enticing longitudinal splits down the skin) just three days later, when the bags can be transferred to the next batch. A time-consuming chore, did I hear someone say? But just think of the resulting pleasure of gorging on one's own ripe figs. There'll probably be, if the job's well done, be more than I can eat myself.

A wild blackberry, growing out of a boundary hedge, is always welcome, and we can stop anathematising them as beastly brambles until the crop is consumed. Autumn-fruiting raspberries are even better. For reasons known best to themselves, birds seem to have lost interest in them by now. The Japanese wineberry is fun. It has the growth of a loganberry, fruiting on last year's long canes. The fruits are clustered and very bright, shining red, but deep maroon by the time they are truly ripe. The flavour is unexciting but it is an excellent kiddies' fruit and it is easy to persuade yourself - or someone else - that they taste nice.

A black mulberry tree is an asset, and you can spend hours, in the course of a week, pottering beneath its branches, while you select the blackest. So sharp, yet stimulating to the palate. We made a mulberry steamed pudding (suet crust) the other day, and in the course of five hours' steaming, the mulberry stalks just melt away and the suet crust becomes lovely and crumbly.

In good soil, mulberries grow quickly and they crop from an early age. But they do need quite a lot of space and you can't sit under one after late July. Their staining abilities are unparalleled. Do, above all, make sure that it is the black mulberry that you are purchasing, not the white, which is a useless thing, unless you mean to keep silkworms.

These are all attractions to visit in one's garden, but the garden's chief attraction is for sitting in and relaxing with champagne or some other sparkling wine, if it is morning ("champagne is best drunk on a Sunday morning when others are in church" an old friend, who died aged 99, use to say), or some stronger spirit in the evening, and good conversation with friends.

But you want the sight of good things around you - dahlias, chrysanthemums and fuchsias are obvious candidates. A pear tree with windfalls beneath it ('Williams' is ideal for this) and Red Admiral and Comma butterflies battening on the rotting flesh, is relaxing to see. Scents are even more important, additional to the aroma of the next meal drifting out from the kitchen. My first favourite, to have near where we sit out, is the common myrtle, Myrtus communis. Both sweet and spicy. And there should be a sweet briar, Rosa rubiginosa, at hand, smelling of stewed apples. Laugh and grow fat, is a good old saying.

webTitle: Why there is no risk of a three-day week this time

fields.headline: Why there is no risk of a three-day week this time
fields.standfirst: 1973 Things have changed since Heath's government fell
fields.trailText: It was a time of paranoia. Tory politicians gathered their families to warn of impending social catastrophe, the head of the civil service told senior ministers the state was in danger, industrialists set up private armies.
fields.body:
It was a time of paranoia. Tory politicians gathered their families to warn of impending social catastrophe, the head of the civil service told senior ministers the state was in danger, industrialists set up private armies.

The prime minister, Ted Heath, ordered power cuts, put the entire labour force on a three-day week, called a snap election on a "who governs Britain?" ticket - and lost.

No wonder memories of the 1973 oil crisis and its aftermath send shivers down spines.

Nearly 30 years ago, as western support for Israel helped tip the balance in the October Middle East war, the Opec oil-producing nations asserted their independence, quadrupling the price of crude and signalling the end of the "golden age" post-war economic boom.

The crisis helped to trigger the stagflationary slump of the 1970s and the worldwide lurch to monetarism.

In Britain, where the economy was already overheating as Mr Heath struggled to contain rising industrial militancy and discontent, the impact was both immediate and dramatic. Petrol prices were ratcheted up as shortages bit, while the powerful miners' union called an overtime ban in a dispute on pay. That became the strike which brought down Mr Heath's government as the country shivered in the dark.

A generation on, there are some distant echoes in current events: the oil blockades, the angry scenes at service stations, the rising petrol prices, the threat of impending shortages. Oil prices this year have registered their second biggest hike since 1973, at a time of rapid growth in the advanced capitalist world.

But the differences are more significant. Inflation is now low and although Opec's share of world oil production has been rising recently, it is still well down on the 56% of 1973. Oil is less important in modern industrial economies and, in Britain's case, the North sea has created a multi-billion pound oil surplus.

Nor do blockades of French lorry drivers, however impressive, quite match up in industrial terms to the vice-like power of 250,000 organised energy workers. And there is nothing of the conflagrationary potential of the 1973 Arab-Israeli war to fuel the crisis - for the moment.

webTitle: France in turmoil as blockade goes on

fields.headline: France in turmoil as blockade goes on
fields.standfirst:
Price war Militant hauliers refuse to ease their stranglehold on petrol supplies


French haulier's association
Eurotunnel
fields.trailText: Militant French road hauliers yesterday refused to ease their crippling five-day stranglehold on fuel supplies, leaving most of the country sinking slowly into paralysis - while British farmers and lorry drivers started similar protests against fuel prices.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris, Helen Carter  and Julia Hartley-Brewer
fields.body:
Militant French road hauliers yesterday refused to ease their crippling five-day stranglehold on fuel supplies, leaving most of the country sinking slowly into paralysis - while British farmers and lorry drivers started similar protests against fuel prices.

Lorry owners from France's leading road hauliers' federation, the FNTR, refused to follow their leaders' call yesterday afternoon to end the blockade, which has closed 14,000 of the country's 17,000 petrol stations and caused severe disruption.

A second big haulage federation, Unostra, went further, asking its members not to abandon the hundreds of roadblocks or some 110 refinery and fuel depot barricades being manned around France.

Providing a crumb of comfort for the embattled government, taxi drivers who had demonstrated en masse on Thursday appeared satisfied with a separate deal wrested from the interior ministry that allowed them to raise the price of a ride by nearly 5% and thus pass on their higher fuel costs to passengers. Coach operators also reached an agree ment with the government and ended their protest.

But their place in the growing queue of demonstrators was immediately taken by driving schools, roadside recovery firms and even private refuse contractors, who yesterday took part in massed go-slow processions or mounted barricades on city approach roads around the country.

The farmers' union, FNSEA, also stepped up its contribution to the campaign, closing railway lines and blocking major road junctions with tractors and promising to take over on the front line of some 110 oil refinery and fuel depot barricades should the hauliers reach a settlement.

"We are not being listened to at all," said the union's president, Luc Guyau. "The government has failed to come up with even a partially satisfactory short-term solution and we stand by our demand for the abolition of state fuel taxes for the agricultural sector."

While French farmers lifted their blockade of the Channel tunnel yesterday, the British transport minister, Lord Macdonald, criticised protesting British farmers and lorry drivers who yesterday targeted an oil refinery and a motorway.

"People have the right to a peaceful demonstration," he said, "but they don't have the right to interrupt the vital supplies in the country, or put the livelihood and convenience of other people at risk."

The demonstrators cut off distribution for several hours from a Shell plant in Merseyside and disrupted traffic on the A1 at Gateshead. Police warned them that their planned blockage of the road would be against the law.

The protesters arrived at the sprawling Stanlow site near Ellesmere Port on Thursday night after an impromptu meeting at St Asaph's livestock market in north Wales.

A Shell spokesman said their business had been effectively shut down for 14 hours and retailers were suffering as a result. "When the protest first took place we took steps to ensure facilities such as hospitals were adequately supplied," said a company spokesman. "But the longer it goes on the worse it is going to get."

An estimated 1.8m litres of petrol in 60 tankers was unable to leave the site because of the blockade. Independent tankers were allowed on and off the site but only one Shell vehicle braved the protesters because it was carrying fuel specifically for ambulances.

At the height of the protest, in the early hours yesterday, 150 farmers and hauliers from north Wales and north-west England had blockaded the site entrance with three tractors. The barricade was moved after six hours when the police threatened to arrest people.

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, warned that hauliers and farmers were planning a day of "direct action" outside refineries and ports on September 18. "These people are decent, honest, hardworking people," he said. "They are being forced out of an honest living by this government's punitive tax increases and they should stop."

Don Foster MP, the Liberal Democrats' transport spokes- man, said he would be proposing a cap on fuel duty, including VAT, later this month.

As the French crisis deepened, Air France suspended flights between Nantes, Rennes, Lyon, Nice and Montpellier airports, the post office warned it could not guarantee services in all regions beyond today, car hire firms said conditions were "critical" in most cities, and large companies including Coca-Cola and Perrier said they would have to halt production.

The French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, who gave the lorry firms a possible way out of the impasse through a complex tax mechanism that would largely offset future price rises, appealed for an end to the campaign.

webTitle: Tax rises fail to cut car journeys

fields.headline: Tax rises fail to cut car journeys
fields.standfirst: Policy  Drivers say levies must be spent on public transport
fields.trailText: Three years ago, when Gordon Brown announced that he was going to continue the Conservatives' strategy of hitting motorists with above-inflation increases in fuel duties, he claimed drivers' pain would be the environment's gain.
fields.body:
Three years ago, when Gordon Brown announced that he was going to continue the Conservatives' strategy of hitting motorists with above-inflation increases in fuel duties, he claimed drivers' pain would be the environment's gain.

The theory was that by increasing the costs of filling up at the pump, the Treasury would persuade drivers to leave the wheels at home and take public transport or walk thus decreasing Britain's emissions of greenhouse gases.

In fact, Labour's decision to increase the escalator on fuel duties to 6% over inflation owed more to the gaping government deficit which they had inherited from the Conservatives than to environmental considerations.

Revenues from petrol taxes bring a healthy £22bn a year to the Treasury coffers. When Mr Brown scrapped the escalator last year, opting to increase fuel duties only by inflation, he deprived the Treasury of £2bn in revenues.

As a result of the rapid increase in duties since Norman Lamont introduced the fuel escalator seven years ago, taxes now account for almost 80% of the cost of a litre of petrol in the UK, the highest proportion in Europe.

But while a welcome largesse for the Treasury, there is scant evidence that higher fuel costs are putting people off driving.

Independent researchers at the Institute for Fiscal Studies estimate that a 10% hike in the cost of driving would reduce the number of miles by less than 5%. "This is not a very large response, which suggests that any attempt to reduce reliance on the car by increasing the cost of fuel will not have been very successful," the researchers note.

The evidence from the UK certainly bears this out. The annual number of miles driven has risen each year since the introduction of escalator, despite rising petrol costs. In 1990 British drivers clocked up a total of 253bn miles between them. Ten years later this had risen by 12% to 284bn.

The real gripe of the green lobby over fuel taxes is that instead of spending the proceeds on researching more environmentally friendly sources of energy or into public transport, it disappears into the Treasury's clutches.

Motoring organisations argue that if fuel taxes must be levied then, the proceeds ought to be spent on tackling congestion on the roads and improving local transport links.

Last year for the first time, Mr Brown broke with the Treasury's long-standing objection to hypothecating tax revenues, announcing that in future, any above inflation increases in fuel duties will be ringfenced for public transport spending.

However, the backlash against higher petrol costs brought about by rising crude oil prices means that Mr Brown is unlikely to risk future above-inflation hikes in petrol duties.

webTitle: Left blacklist man joins euro fight

fields.headline: Left blacklist man joins euro fight
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: One of Business for Sterling's campaigners against the euro formerly headed the extreme rightwing Economic League, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
One of Business for Sterling's campaigners against the euro formerly headed the extreme rightwing Economic League, it was revealed yesterday.

Stan Hardy was director general of the league, which kept files on more than 22,000 blacklisted "subversives" before it was wound up in 1994.

Now Yorkshire and Humberside regional chairman of Business for Sterling, Mr Hardy was one of 337 people heading the "Euro No" campaign launched this week jointly by Business for Sterling and the New Europe campaign of Lord Owen. They say they are for Europe but against the single currency.

Mr Hardy is also Yorkshire director of the Institute of Directors, and until last year through his family firm, Caprim Ltd, continued to alert businesses to individuals and organisations he claimed were opposed to private enterprise.

The Economic League was set up in 1919 to fight Bolshevism and intervened in industrial relations until wound up in 1994 after complaints of it holding inaccurate information on individuals; under data law it would have had to open its files. It had 40 current Labour MPs on its files, including the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and prominent trade unionists, as well as journalists and thousands of shopfloor workers.

Through Caprim, Mr Hardy continued warning firms of those he believed could "weaken a company's ability to manage its affairs profitably". He condemned the Ethical Investment Research Service for "busybodyness" in drawing investors' attention to whether firms supplied services to the defence ministry, or whether furniture firms used tropical hardwoods. His monitor warned: "Companies need to be warned what these organisations are saying and planning. Caprim provides this information. And assesses the strength of the threat. And advises on appropriate action."

Last year, when Mr Hardy joined the institute, he was asked to divest himself of his company interests to avoid any "conflict of interest". He no longer has any personal involvement in the firm. A Business for Sterling spokesman said: "We are not aware of [Mr Hardy's past]. We do not think this has anything to do with the campaign against the euro." The Guardian tried to contact Mr Hardy but he was not available for comment.

And advises on appropriate action." Last year, when Mr Hardy joined the institute, he was asked to divest himself of his company interests to avoid any "conflict of interest". He no longer has any personal involvement in the firm. A Business for Sterling spokesman said: "We are not aware of [Mr Hardy's past]. We do not think this has anything to do with the campaign against the euro." The Guardian tried to contact Mr Hardy but he was not available for comment.

webTitle: Farmers' oil plant blockade frustrated

fields.headline: Farmers' oil plant blockade frustrated
fields.standfirst: Rural protest: Tankers halted in all-night demo until police step in
fields.trailText: Farming is Brynle Williams' life - it is the only job he has known in 51 years. He is the third generation of farmers to have tended 200 acres of land at Cilcain between Ruthin and Mold in north Wales.
fields.body:
Farming is Brynle Williams' life - it is the only job he has known in 51 years. He is the third generation of farmers to have tended 200 acres of land at Cilcain between Ruthin and Mold in north Wales.

But the fuel crisis threatens to put him out of business. Not only does he have to pay more for his vet's bills but the cost of other basics, such as fertiliser and meal for the animals, has risen as a direct result of the fuel price rises.

Mr Williams has not made a profit in four years and is existing only with the grace of his bank. It now costs him an extra £80 a month to run his tractors - the red diesel which powers them has increased from 14.9 pence a litre in May to 23.9 pence.

He spent a whole day and night blockading Shell's oil distribution refinery at Stanlow, Cheshire. "I have been up since 5am on Thursday and I am only here because I want the government to revoke this unfair tax on fuel," he said yesterday.

"We are not here to mimic the French farmers - that is not our ambition - we just want the government to take action. The reason they are not interested is because farmers only form 2% of the electorate - perhaps this will change if we involve more people."

Philip Robinson, a dairy, beef and sheep farmer from Nannerch, near Mold, said the farmers felt they were being kicked by the government when they were at their lowest ebb.

"Fuel prices are like the final nail in the coffin for farmers," he said. "Our profit margins have already been cut back to the bone. Everything comes down to fuel prices in the end and it affects us in so many ways. We have had so many crises in farming, but this has put the top hat on it for us."

Mr Williams is the vice-chairman of the Farmers' Union of Wales and the organiser of the blockade. At its height, around 150 protesters from north Wales and the north-west blockaded the oil distribution terminal throughout Thursday night.

Yesterday afternoon, the numbers at the Shell plant had dwindled to around 40 farmers and hauliers at entrance number two, but more sup porters were expected to arrive over the weekend.

The site, which covers four square miles, dominates the surrounding flat Cheshire countryside. It is scarred by huge steel pipes, storage containers, chimneys and the constantly flickering flame of a flare system which burns excess gas. Burning oil and petrol smells linger in the air.

On Thursday night, the protesters arrived at the plant after an emotional meeting of farmers at St Asaph market in north Wales. Having decided to barricade the plant, three tractors were used to block the tankers' entrance and stop them entering or leaving.

At 4am, the tractors were finally moved after police reinforcements arrived and told the farmers that under section 241 of the 1992 trade union and labour relations act they had to move or be arrested.

Within 10 minutes, the immediate area was cleared. But 60 of Shell's tankers - capable of carrying 30,000 litres of fuel each - remained behind the wire fences yesterday as company officials decided it was not safe for them to drive past the remains of the blockade.

Just one Shell tanker was allowed through when the dri ver showed protesters documents proving he was delivering fuel for ambulances.

Tankers belonging to other petrol companies were allowed through. The farmers and hauliers looked on in disgust. Officials at Shell admitted that the protest had begun to affect its petrol stations in the north-west, parts of Yorkshire and up to the borders.

The protesters said they were pleased that petrol stations in the area would soon begin to run out of fuel.

"It is sad for the general public who will feel the effect in the long run," said one farmer. "But at the end of the day it is the government we are angry with and we just hope that people will support us."

People from the nearby village of Elton were clearly supportive of the farmers. One woman dropped off a carrier bag full of biscuits for the campaigners. Later a box of soft drinks was donated by a villager.

Many passing cars sounded their horns in support and some drivers raised their fists in a show of encouragement. A lorry with: "Fair play its time to stop screwing us" drove past to cheers.

The protesters, however, are vowing to stay put until the government takes action to reduce tax on fuel.

As the protest continued, around 20 hauliers' lorries and dozens of cars were parked on the private road leading up to the oil refinery. Police cordoned off the area to prevent traffic jams building up. Around 50 police officers from Cheshire police patrolled the area.

One lorry driver drove past sounding his horn and carrying a sign on the back of his lorry: "This is only the start of things to come, so give in now Mr Blair."
